29866297.review:
By all accords I see the first person shooter genre as something of a terrible plague on mankind. It kills millions and spares no one, its a terrible way to die but this shit still piles up like Mcrib orders. Its not to say that it doesn’t have its high and lows, but rather its become somewhat of a mainstay in the modern gaming industry, and a quite unwelcome one at that. In fact the industry has a become a breeding ground for generic garbage. To be honest, garbage might be too kind of a word to describe what the genre has devolved into, But that’s a story for another day buckaroo. 

In the case of early FPS games I can say this much, at least it felt like I was playing a game and not a dribble of cinematic boredom as contrived and cliché as Jar Jar Abrams and his infatuated fan base. But I’m getting ahead of myself as I walk down a path of that I know I cannot return. In the meantime, let us revel in what is the genius of Quake. 

Quake can probably be best describe as the peculiar case of taking Lovecraft, Heavy metal, and guns galore and mixing it with its own touch of Nine Inch Nail ambiance. I'm no Nine Inch Nail fan but even I can appeciate a good mindfuck that is the soundtrack to this game. However, perhaps that’s what stands out most about Quake… is The Lovecraft worship. No, were not talking about the sorry excuse of a Elric Rip-off style worship imbedded into the Witcher franchise, were talking about a disturbing reimaging of the idea of twisted. A twisted that crawls up your spine and pulls it out while at last laughing in your face spitting your own blood back into your eyes. Yeah a cruel sight, but I would be damned if it didn’t hit the mark and make me ask for seconds. Quake is no different. It doesn’t apologize, it doesn’t hold your hand, and it sure as hell doesn’t slow down so you can duck behind cover and whimper like a little shit as you wait for the guillotine to chop your sorry ass in two. You shouldn't be ducking to save your life you should be blowing your enemies into pieces to save your life. In a time where Iron sights where but a distant idea, and quick action events were nothing more than a way of describing your sex life Quake stood the test of time as a master of its craft. It’s FPS at its best, with no compromises and no Bull$*&#. You want filler, well take that crap back to anime and give it a resounding middle finger while your at it because that doesn’t exist here. This is pure mayhem and death like never before all in its own twisted world to boot. It's not here to pour out the horrors of war or to make you feel for someone its here to blast you away like a good Bolt Thrower riff. I didn't ask for a melodrama I asked for a damn game, and Quake gave that and more. 

To say that this is a doom clone would be a little bit of wrong misrepresentation of what is otherwise a ground breaking game in not just the FPS genre but in 3D gaming at large. I’m not here to give a history lesson but to be frank with you, this game deserves more than just praise. Quake expanded the graph from being purely horizontal to being horizontal, vertical and misdirectional (if ever that was a word) without taking a second to stop and say “well my works done here lets hit the can…”. Yeah, enjoyed the most recent entry in the Doom series (Doom 4) then you can thank Quake (and Id software who HELPED make the recent DOOM) for making what is practically an identical experience. Let’s be honest, Doom needed a little Quake to take it out of its primordial roots. No shame in what Doom started as but a facelift didn’t hurt this Hollywood failure from getting a deserving reboot. 

In short, Quake is to FPS what Judas Priest is to metal. It’s the fucking embodiment of FPS at its best. I couldn’t recommend this game more. Between the twisted creatures, the atmospheric environment, and a soundtrack that even Penderecki would smile in glee and lube up for... this game was FPS heaven, before cliché after anime level cliché took over the industry and Metal Gear Solid was praised as the second coming of gamer christ we had Quake. Praise the high fathers of whatever mad studio (Id studio) had the balls to do what most couldn't, make a great FPS! 

Sadly, we have yet to get a proper sequel to this game, and it doesn’t look promising in the future. But hell, it doesn’t stop you from going and getting this damn game. If I have any criticism of the steam version it would be simple… “Where the hell is the soundtrack?” I mean I understand copyrights a Bitch, but how hard is it really to get such a thing done, I shouldn’t feel the need to make it an addition to the game but such is life. If it isn’t already obvious get this game… Better yet, get the real version of this game and enjoy you what FPS could, and should be.

This is MasterOfThePit calling…
“Praise to Deus Ex and praise Kek...Out”

29792303.review:
Quake was id Software's follow-up to DOOM, so right off the bat it had a lot to live up to. At the same time, Duke Nukem 3D had come out just a few months earlier, and had raised the shooter bar by quite a lot (according to people at the time). With these external circumstances, Quake under a lot of pressure to perform; luckily, at the time it was seen as amazing and technically astounding (although divisive). Having completed it, I'd say it's pretty damn good, better than Duke Nukem 3D but not as good as DOOM.

Quake is, tonally and aesthetically, very different from DOOM in some ways and very similar in others. Like DOOM, it's about fighting horrible nightmare creatures in their strange realm; however, while DOOM is basically the tonal equivalent of someone covered in tattoos and piercings screaming in your ear for five hours, Quake is more grim, gloomy, and gothic. It works very hard to be haunting and unsettling, and pulls it off pretty well, with an off-kilter, disjointed soundtrack of wailing guitars and ambient noise (that you have to install a patch to have on the Steam version, which is a bit of a pisser), a grimy, subdued color palette (it's all brown and gray), plenty of shadows, and lots of Lovecraftian elements. It's all very surreal, and I like it a lot.

This was the first fully 3D FPS (thanks to those wizards at id), and it does a very good job of introducing this new mechanic. There's a lot of verticality in the level design that could only have happened with 3D, and the models are all pretty well-done. Unfortunately, a few things are pretty simplistic because of the limitations of 3D (you can't have DOOM's spectacular gore, basically), but it works out well enough nonetheless.

The shooting is excellent. There are 5 weapons, three of which have upgraded versions that you can also collect (and then never use the basic ones again) and each has its niche in gameplay. More importantly, they all feel great to use, which is mostly a function of the sound design, which is fantastic. The monsters are more varied, and they're all pretty fun to fight (except for the Ogres, because Jesus fuckin' Christ). The game also showers you with ammo, because most of the monsters take plenty of hits (I think I ran out of shotgun shells only twice). It's all very fast-paced and flow-y and everything I want out of a 90s FPS, gameplay-wise. 

The level design is not as great. It's got the aforementioned verticality, but it's also about as screwy and hard to figure out as 90s FPS level design gets, which is not helped by the bizarre absence of a map (I guess they couldn't figure out how to generate one in 3D, where levels can overlap each other). The episode structure also returns, which is dumb, especially considering they realized that they could drop it back in DOOM 2. I'm guessing the levels are designed as such to pad out the game time, which is otherwise not that long. There're only 27 of them, each completable in about 5 minutes if you know what you're doing.

There's no use button for some reason. You just stand next to things you want activated, although you occasionally shoot them instead.

The bosses are pretty easy. They're both puzzles, not shootouts, and one of the puzzles is incredibly easy do while the other is easy to accomplish but ridiculously unintuitive to figure out.

All the text is really tiny.

Overall, Quake's a pretty damn good game. It hasn't aged perfectly (anti-aliasing the textures would be a good start), but it's still very well-designed and a barrel of fun. Also, it's been astonishingly influential; pretty much every FPS from the past 20 years owes something to Quake, more so than even DOOM. For all of these reasons, I recommend it.

29748365.review:
20 évnyi lemaradásomat igyekszem már legalább 10 éve pótolni, mert állandóan tologattam, halogattam a Quake végigjátszást, egészen mostanáig. Nem feltételezem, hogy különösebb bemutatásra szorulna a játék. A Quake annak idején a 3D éra egyik úttörője volt, ami tovább népszerűsítette a már akkor is egyre csak növekvő FPS zsánert. Egy igazi, hamisítatlan Run 'N Gun játék, amelyet legtöbben az eszeveszett tempója miatt imádnak, szóval nem is csoda, hogy évekig az egyik legnépszerűbb többjátékos lövölde volt. Őszintén megvallva picit ezért is óckodtam tőle, mert nekem a Quake 3 gyors tempója nem igazán feküdt, ezért én mindig is Unreal Tournament párti voltam. Viszont ha nem a multiplayer élményt tekintem elsődlegesnek, abban az esetben ennek a szöges ellentétét kell állítanom: a Quake egyjátékos kampánya személy szerint sokkal jobban megfogott a maga poklot idéző atmoszférájával, mint a két évvel későbbi Unreal, ami szintén jó játék volt, de emellett kurvára unalmas is. Tök jól esett átszaladni és agyatlanul végiglövöldözni a pályákon, amelyek olykor nem tartanak tovább 3 percnél, főleg ha az ember előszeretettel vág le bizonyos szakaszokat egy kis rocketjump-pal. Sajnos ez képes hanyatt vágni a tartalomnak is, mert ezáltal a négy fejezet potom 3 óra alatt végigpörgethető, de ezt nem feltétlen éreztem negatívumnak. Persze a két küldetéslemez megvásárlásával ez tovább növelhető plusz két-két órával, amelyek még több pályát, ellenfelet, zenét és fegyvert adnak hozzá az alapjátékhoz, de magán a dinamikán, a hangulaton és a recepten semmit nem változtatnak, szóval ahelyett, hogy kétszer leírnám ugyan azt, inkább itt, az alapjátékkal egy kalap alá véve értékelem a kiegészítőket is. Biztos vagyok benne, hogy ha valamikor a kilencvenes évek végén kerülök ennek a játéknak a közelébe, akkor éjjel nappal ezt toltam volna, viszont szerencsére úgy érzem, hogy még most is képes volt megfogni és hajlok a jövőbeli újrajátszásra is.

Mint a legtöbb régi játék esetében, sajnos a Quake is erős hiányosságokkal rendelkezik. A zenét egy az egyben kivágták a Steam kiadásból (aki ismeri a RedBook Audio működését, valószínűleg tudja, milyen okból kifolyólag) így ha csak nem rendelkezel az eredeti lemezes példánnyal, vagy nem pörög a meghajtódban [strike]egy virágbolti[/strike] egy jó barátodtól kölcsönkért példány, akkor kénytelen leszel a puskadurranások, robbanások, nyögések és halálsikolyok remixére végigtolni a játékot. Vagy alternatív megoldásként bevághatod az OST-t a háttérbe, had dübörögjön anyádék /a lakóház /az utca /a kutyád legnagyobb örömére, miközben megállás nélkül szidják a családfádat, 3 generációig visszamenőleg. Újabb rendszereken a Windowsos átirat elég csúnyán fest, rosszul is fut és ha jól tudom, csak szoftveres módban hajlandó rotyogni ami valljuk be... nem a leggusztusosabb látvány a mai szemnek. A GLQuake mód ennek ellenére nagyon szépen fut, habár ahhoz, hogy nagyobb felbontásban is fusson kicsit varázsolni kell a paraméterekkel és a vertikális egérmozgást is a konzolból kell külön aktiválni... minden indításnál, de egy két apróbb defekttől eltekintvén kiválóan fut a játék, bármiféle barmolás nélkül. Aki viszont az ultimate arany középutat keresi, az tengernyi source port közül válogathat. Én személy szerint a DirectQ-t ajánlom, mert ezzel kell a legkevesebbet tökölni, támogatja az .ogg formátumú zenék lejátszását, könnyedén, a játék menüjéből engedi belőni a FullHD felbontást és nem utolsó sorban szerintem ez a leghűebb az eredeti látványvilághoz, mellőzve mindenféle csilli-villi dinamikus fény effektet meg marhaságot, amelyek nem igazán illenek ehhez a játékhoz.

29735328.review:
Quake is a FPS masterpiece.
Quake took what DOOM started and rocket jumped it into your face.
A Lovecraftien Horror setting paired with a soundtrack by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails (not included in Steam release due to being on the physical disc. check the guides for info), and non stop, rust covered, blood soaked carnage.
A community that is still active and  pumping out great maps and mods and mutiplayer that is still just as fun now as it ever was.

An absolute classic. Would lean on the left mouse button again.

29708647.review:
For me, Quake is the real sequel to Doom 2. It shows a natural progression in design and technology, and it has a TON of atmosphere. There are so many levels that wouldn't look out of place in a Doom game. It literally just feels like a more difficult, atmospheric and complex version of previous Doom. 
I know I'm in the minority, but I honestly think Quake 1 surpassed the original two Doom games. 
That all said though, Quake still holds up. The levels are huge and complex, the music is incredibly atmospheric, and the guns are satisfying as all hell to use. If you haven't played Quake, you're doing yourself a disservice.

29642505.review:
After all these years, after the rise of Call of Duty, Battlefield, the advent of free to play, Half-Life, and the entire history of the modern FPS, Quake still more than stands up. 

This is a very important game in the development of the FPS genre and is often cited as the point where the term FPS was coined and the term "Doom-clone" was dropped. It also brought us such classic things as rocket jumping and bunny hopping.

You're going to crawl through legions of Eldritch horrors which offer balanced and distinct challenges. The weapon selection is small, but well defined in its capabilities and roles.

For $5, you can get currency for some terrible Free to Play or you can play one of the best FPS's ever crafted. Just do yourself a favor and seek out QuakeSpasm if you do.

29433365.review:
Also, ich habe Quake gerade zum ersten Mal überhaupt gespielt und durchgezockt und das Game ist echt einfach eine Wucht. Es sieht zwar wegen der 3D Optik (für mich) "schlimmer" aus als die ersten beiden DOOMs, aber das tut dem Gameplay keinen Abbruch: Nicht vergessen jedoch die Konsole zu öffnen und "+mlook" einzugeben, damit man sich frei umsehen kann und ab geht es. 

Grundsätzlich, ist es ziemlich genau das, was man von einem id Shooter erwartet: Irre schnell, manchmal frustrierend, düster, blutig, vollgespickt mit Geheimnissen und fiesen Kreaturen und coolen Waffen. Die alten Shooter haben irgendwie einfach so einen herrlichen Arcade-Einschlag, weswegen man sie wunderbar mal kurz starten kann und losfetzt, aber auch genauso gut Stunde umd Stunde damit verbringen kann. 

Im Vergleich mit DOOM 1 und DOOM 2 kann ich nur sagen, dass mir Quake etwas weniger gefällt. DOOM hat einfach einen etwas cooleren Touch, was das Gegnerdesign und die Welten angeht. Teilweise ist das Game einfach so dermaßen düster, dass man die Gegner einfach nicht sieht und mehr oder minder blind feuert. Darüber hinaus fand ich im speziellen die vierte und letzte Episode leicht übertrieben was den Verwirrungsgrad und den Schwierigkeitsgrad angeht und ich komme nicht so leicht ins Schwitzen. 
Leider fehlt auch der Soundtrack von Nine Inch Nails, was wirklich schade ist. Ich kenne ihn zwar nicht, aber wenn ich mir vorstelle, die geniale Musik aus DOOM würde fehlen, wäre auch die Hälfte des Flairs weg. 

Auf jeden Fall das Geld wert, wenn man auf Klassiker und speziell klassische Shooter steht. Es erinnert durchaus stark an DOOM. Wenn DOOM ein fleischgewordenes Slayer-Album ist, kann man Quake wohl am ehesten mit den ersten Alben von Machine Head vergleichen: Schwer wie blei im Ton, schnell und explosiv in der Ausführung.

29424707.review:
Классика жанра шутеров о которой уже многое сказано. Поэтому скажу о субъективном. В своё время Quake, в отличии от DOOM и иных шутеров, полностью прошёл мимо меня (кроме частично третьей части) и особого интереса не вызывал. В библиотеке лежит уже некоторое время, проходить же его начал только сейчас.

Особенности:

* 28 уровней, 4 секретных, на которые я не стал заходить. Судя по ютубу ничего интересного из себя не представляют. Если прохождение ряда иных шутеров было скорее перфикционистким, то Quake больше ориентировал по своему строению на быстрый доход до конца - ряд уровней укладываются здесь буквально в 3 минуты. Прохождение я начал со сложности Hard, всего доступно четыре таковых, и третьего эпизода. Не знаю дозволяет ли игра проходить эпизоды не последовательно, или я загрузил не то сохранение, но пришлось мне пройти 3 эпизод два раза. В секретные зоны попадал волей случая, есть несколько примечательных.
* 8 видов оружия.
* Бонусы. Из особенного, что пошло именно от Quake, 4-х кратный урон.
* 13 типов врагов, 2 босса.
* Оригинальная концовка, что ввела понятие телефрага.
* Ряд отсылок/пасхалок, в частности к наследию D&D в трактовке ID (см. книгу "Masters of Doom", есть на русском от МИФ) и Лавкрафту.
* Местный "Normal" по мне равноценен Ultra-Violence в DOOM и Uber в современном Wolfenstein: The New Order. Hard - Nightmare в современном DOOM. Уровень сложности Nightmare здесь не проверял, открывается как секретка.
* ~ 6,5 часов (учитывая, что повторял 3 эпизод) на полное прохождение 4 эпизодов и босса, без захода на 4 секретных уровня и полный анализ секретов на уровнях.
* GLQuake c поддержкой OpenGL и несколько более продвинутой графикой в наличии.
* Нет карты.

Плюсы:

+ Доработанная схема более ранних игр ID, основное новведение - полноценный переход в 3D. Появилась возможность смотреть вверх и вниз, прыжок, поддержка глобального мультиплеера, вывод таких понятий как deatchmatch и speedrun на новый уровень.
+ По-прежнему хорошо играется без каких-либо аддонов и особых ковыряний в настройках.
+ Сообщество игроков до сих пор выпускает новые уровни и моды. К 20-летию Quake вышел эпизод от Machine Games.

Минусы:

? Quake стал первым намёком на акцент Кармака - приоритет технологий в противовес всему остальному (дизайн, звук, сюжет и т.д.) В более поздних играх, вроде RAGE, этот аспект будет виден сильнее. Отсюда отчасти и номинальный сюжет (как и отсутствие кстати такового по большей части в DOOM), буро-серо-коричная палитра уровней и довольно уступающий дизайн таковых тому же DOOM и Heretic. Сложно сказать, что было бы с игрой не было бы в команде разработчиков Американа Макги, что заменил Ромеро... С другой стороны доступность движка породила затем много известных игр (см. https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quake#/media/File:Quake_-_family_tree.svg)
- Проблемы с разрешением в настройках игры.
- Вырезана музыка. Разработчики Steam-порта поленились интегрировать то, что ранее требовало наличие диска в приводе.
- Сетевой режим попрежнему стартует не в 2 клика, нужно возиться в настройках. Хороший пример здесь - steam-версия Duke Nukem 3D.
- Нет поддержки Steam Workshop (опять же если сравнить с Duke 3D).

Добавлю. Последние два минуса я бы обозначил приемлимыми для DOOM (конец 1993'го, определённая специфика), но для игры 1996'го, шутера, с портом в Steam, уже не считаю таковым. В своё время смогли с другом запустить "сюжетный кооператив с ботами и сохранением прогресса в миссиях" на Windows 7 в стратегии образца 1995'го, Battle Isle 3, где поддержки сетевого режима как такового нет, только локальный LAN. Использовали Hamachi, гостевые учётные записи и одну общедоступную папку на одном из ПК, чтобы хранить сохранения. Фанаты же в своё время отправляли сохранения по почте после каждого хода, что, к слову (завязка на почту), до некоторых пор считалось нормой в той же серии Civilization.

Вердикт? Если вам по душе старые шутеры, то, среди прочего, стоит обратить внимание и на Quake.

29347769.review:
This is a game that's not only aged well, but arguably gotten better with age. It's stylish, it's simple, it's a hell of a lot of fun. In what other game do you get a wild juxtaposition of sci-fi themes, anachronistic medieval environments, and demonic enemies all in the same package? If you like first person shooters, chances are your favorite fps uses a distant branch of the Quake engine and those of you who play TF2 frequently might find a comforting familiarity with the controls and weapons.

The game still has an active modding community to this day, and while not as prolific as Doom, I find this game more enjoyable and a visual treat especially as the "low poly pixel aesthetic" is becoming popular again and has a much tighter art direction.

Just be sure to get a modern engine like Darkplaces or Quakespasm. The steam release doesn't include the music so you'll have to download that. I /highly/ recommend playing with the music on as it gives a unique and chilling atmosphere to the game like nothing else.

If you finish up Quake and are looking for more action, there are plenty of maps and mods to download that continue the Quake experience. One I highly recommend is Arcane Dimensions if you're looking for new weapons, new enemies, and newer, bigger worlds to explore.

29293883.review:
Rok 1996 był bardzo dobrym rokiem dla graczy, a miłośnicy strzelanek to już w ogóle mieli fajnie. Tego właśnie roku ukazały się dwa giganty gatunku, których ślad pozostawiony w branży jest widoczny po dziś dzień. Pierwszą z nich był pełen wulgarnego humoru, striptizerek, kosmitów oraz niezobowiązującej jatki Duke Nukem 3D. Drugim był ponury, złowieszczy, brutalny Quake.

Podobnie jak w Doomie jesteśmy od razu rzucani w wir akcji. Nawet wybór poziomu trudności jest interaktywny. Potem jest już tylko rzeź do samego końca. Gdyby ktoś jednak chciał wiedzieć, po kiego grzyba to wszystko robimy, po zakończeniu każdego rozdziału może poczytać wyjaśnienie. Podobno starożytna istota – Shub-Niggurath – chce zawładnąć krainą Quake. Abyśmy  mieli jakiekolwiek szanse w starciu z poczwarą, musimy udać się do czterech królestw / wymiarów krainy po magiczne runy. Tylko z ich pomocą powstrzymamy kreaturę i jej armię potworów! Paradoksalnie, jeśli brać pod uwagę, co się działo z tym gatunkiem gier w okresie wydania wielkiego Q, powyższa fabuła jest co najmniej w porządku, a nawet jeśli nie, to przynajmniej nie przeszkadza.

Na grę składają się cztery epizody zawierające po 7-8 map (w tym ukryte), które można rozegrać na jednym z czterech (jeden ukryty) poziomów trudności. Po Doomie niektóre FPSy starały się urozmaicić rozgrywkę w ten, czy inny sposób (np. w Hereticu wprowadzono przedmioty, które można wykorzystać później niż w momencie podniesienia). Quake jednak trzyma się kurczowo korzeni: naszym celem jest znaleźć wyjście z labiryntu, znajdźki odpalają się od razu, a od czasu do czasu potrzebny będzie klucz. Jednakże nowy silnik pozwolił także na rozwinięcie tej formuły. Autorzy pozwolili sobie na zabawę fizyką (zmienna grawitacja, odbijające się granaty, strzał piorunem zadający obrażenia wszystkim znajdującym się w wodzie itd.), z dużo większą swobodą rozmieścili ruchome elementy, pułapki, portale i przełączniki, z których nie wszystkie wymagają bezpośredniego użycia (można do nich strzelać).

Nie jestem pewien, czy to tylko moje wrażenie, ale wydaje mi się, iż Quake jest bardziej dynamiczny od swojego poprzednika.  Zarówno przeciwnicy, jak i nasza postać ruszają się szybko, broń zmienia się w mgnieniu oka, a rakietnica
wywala pociski w takim tempie, że głowa mała. Na dokładkę sterowanie jest mega precyzyjne, dzięki czemu zarówno starcia z potworami, jak i sekwencje platformowe nie sprawiają problemów. Nawet niekiedy dziko poukrywane sekretne miejsca nie frustrują.  Przeciwnicy są dość urozmaiceni, a po kuzynach z Dooma odziedziczyli zapał do walki i zdarza im się tłuc między sobą. Niektóre ich ruchy mogłyby mieć więcej klatek animacji. Ciekawostką jest to, że bossów mamy raptem dwóch (w Doomie też tylu było, ale rozmieszczenie było bardziej tradycyjne). Jeden na zakończenie pierwszego rozdziału, a drugi po przejściu wszystkich. Z obydwoma walczy się, zważywszy na czas wydania gry, dość niekonwencjonalnie (ale to na plus).

Co prawda 3D w Quake’u nie jest takie do końca pełne, jednak stoi o krok dalej od Duke Nukem 3D i o ile graficznie Q strasznie się zestarzał (co widać zwłaszcza po teksturach), o tyle projekty poziomów nadal dobrze się trzymają i nieostrożnemu graczowi potrafią dać w kość. Niektóre z nich są tak świetnie znane i lubiane, iż dzięki modderom doczekały się wersji do innych gier (o tobie mówię, Q1DM4!). Do samego Q wyszło tyle modów, że podrasowanie jego wyglądu do współczesnych standardów nie powinno sprawić trudności (już nie wspominając o tym, że sama podstawowa gra jest wciąż tak elastyczna w konfiguracji, jak mało która).

Z muzyką sprawa ma się nieco inaczej. Odpowiedzialny za nią Trent Reznor odwalił kawał świetnej, idealnie wpasowującej się w warstwę wizualną roboty. Z tymże osobiście wolę słuchać jego utworów poza grą. Przyczyna tego stanu rzeczy jest nieco dziwna. Gdy Quake trafił na rynek, sprzedawany był na płycie CD. W tamtych czasach w Polsce napęd CD nie był jeszcze standardem, w związku z czym dużą popularnością cieszyły się ripy gier. Te pozbawione muzyki audio, cutscenek i generalnie całego dobrodziejstwa uzasadniającego wrzucenie gry na płytę, przenosiło się na dyskietkach 3,5 cala (w przypadku Quake’a było to chyba 16 dyskietek ze spakowaną, np. ARJem grą). Taka właśnie wersja (bez muzyki) trafiła pierwotnie w moje ręce, a ilość czasu spędzona na mordowaniu potworów, botów, kolegów i rodzeństwa (Multiplayer mimo ubogiej listy trybów gry (bodajże coop + Deatchmatch) swoim tempem i miodnością przebija niejedną współczesną produkcję) bez akompaniamentu twórczości Reznora sprawiła, że po dziś dzień w Q gra mi się lepiej bez muzyki.

Jeśli chodzi o wady, mógłbym wymienić dwie, z czego jedna trochę na siłę. Po pierwsze: arsenał. Dostępna broń sprawdza się znakomicie zarówno w trybie single, jak i multiplayer, ale zróżnicowaniem nie grzeszy (topór, 2x shotgun, 2x nailgun, 2x rakietowe (wyrzutnia i granatnik) oraz Thunderbolt). Po drugie: muzyka. Obecnie, żeby odtworzyć oryginalną ścieżkę w taki sposób, jak to miało miejsce w wersji CD, trzeba się
nagimnastykować.

W dobie tytułów, które dynamiką, rozgrywką i nazwą starają się nawiązywać do klasyków gatunku (dwie ostatnie odsłony Wolfensteina i Doom 2016) do wielkiego Q wciąż warto powrócić. Jest to szybka, klimaciarska i nadal bardzo miodna gra, której warto spróbować nie tylko przez wzgląd na aspekt historyczny. Moja ocena: 5-.

http://kresowyblog.blogspot.com/2016/05/quake.html

Например, с огромным удовольствием был мной пройден первый Unreal. Серию QUAKE я, конечно же, никак не мог пройти мимо. Вторая часть - первая игра в моей жизни. А первая как-то прошла мимо. Справедливости ради, с некоторыми противниками сражаться было интересно. В общем, игру стоит попробовать пройти. Но тратить деньги и играть в стимовскую версию - нет. Тот редкий случай, когда лучше на торренте скачать хороший репак и не портить себе нервы.

Basta cercare un po in internet mod come HD QUAKE che portano il gioco ai giorni nostri con texture migliorate e piccole migliorie generali, oppure come me gustarsi il gioco cosi come mamma Id lo ha creato nel 1995.

29052121.review:
Quake, twenty years on, is still an amazing game that has endured the test of time. I played it for the first time only last year and I enjoyed it immensely. The gameplay is incredibly fast and smooth--it differs itself from Dooms methodical room-clearing by being all about movement. The only way to play this game is on the hardest difficulties, when rooms filled with obsticales are littered with dozens of enemies and you're utilizing the game's fast paced movements and gravitational physics to bounce around at high speeds, doging projectiles and spraying bullets everywhere. Quake is a punishing game that rewards constant vigilance with your movement, and it's what makes the game shine. Every level is intense on an emotional and logical level, so no encounter is ever dull or boring. It's immensely rich, gameplay-wise.

Aesthetically, the vistuals are naturally dated, but I think this works in the game's favor. If Doom was that excitable 80s metal head who's presence demands attention, Quake is that mid-90s industrial loner in the corner, brooding quietly. The levels are a mishmash of industrial gothic castles and cathedrals, but the atmosphere itself is a perpetual sense of nihilism and dread. The choppy and rusty graphics just work in favor of the game's visuals.

This is aided immensely by Trent Reznor's work on the sound design. The sound effects are meaty, the guns sound piercing and LOUD, as they should, and grabbing an ammo box gives such a satisfying CHH-CHH sound that I can still hear it now. It's not just the sound effects either--the music is also equally amazing. It's one of the best ambient-droning-industrial soundtracks out there for video games, and the fact that it's not somehow packaged in the Steam release is an absolute shame, since I can't imagine ever playing this game without music. If you are going to buy it on here, get a CD of the game and keep it in your harddrive, or use the music pack mods. I cannot stress that enough. Playing this game without the gloomy, screeching soundtrack takes away so much to what this game already has to offer.

Playing Quake is like seeing all the rings on the inside of a tree-stump for late 90s, early 2000s PC FPS games. Absolutely play it.

28878766.review:
Quake is, in my opinion, far more revolutionary to the FPS genre than DOOM.

Quake pioneered:

[*] Mouselook/WASD
[*] Swimming
[*] Rocketjumping/bunnyhopping
[*] Polygon models
[*] Level design via enemy archtypes and placement relative to 3D gemometry
[*] Machinima

Sadly, steam's digital download doesn't feature the soundtrack. Just open up the track per level via youtube.

It's also a shame that we haven't had a proper sequal in over 20 years (if you don't fight entities straight out of Lovecraft with a bloody battleaxe, shotguns, nailguns and explosives in medieval settings, it's not canon).

If you remotely consider yourself a fan of the FPS genre, buy this game, it's your history.

28700393.review:
1996.  One of the very first full 3d first person shooters.   combine the fast-paced action from Doom and throw in some hellish-outerworldly evil with a faint scent of medieval vibe to it while Ogre's with chainsaws and grenade launchers, undead knights and even those raptor things that spring out of the dark and rip you to shreds.

   You also got weapons that that makes today's military firearms in modern fps shooters look like kindergarden playsets that you find in toys r us, such as nailguns, shotguns..even the supershotgun loads it's shells in automatically in a second, grenade launchers, thunderbolt guns (don't shoot that in the water for the love of god) and even iconic Rocket Launcher that shat rockets which gave great results, and also gave birth to a risky technique called "rocket jumping"...and... that weapon made an unfortunate dumbed down return on Team Fortress 2 for the Soldier class with only 4 shots in the chamber before you have to reload.  bummer.  you don't ever reload the QUAKE rocket launcher.  EVER.

The Story of QUAKE has you going through slipgate dimensions to stop this thing from sending their armies of unspeakable evil to earth.  Yea it's got that Doom vibe to it.  each set of 8 or 10 levels are all broken up into episodes and you just walk to the area whichever episode you want to play.  I'd start with episode 1 if I were you.   You just clear out each section that's crawling with hostiles, so you just shoot to kill, find any keys, and move on to the next level.  Find better weapons as you go, and kill each boss at the end of the episode and at the final boss in the game, you have to telefrag it.  You figure it out how to do that.  It's not that hard.

While Doom pioneered the term deathmatch for multiplayer, Quake Perfected it and brought a new name to first person shooters involving a competition based on weapon/item/powerup pickups, player movement, map knowledge, weapon skill: Arena FPS.
Unfortuntatly, there's not much people online but you can check out Quake World and other communities that are still around keeping this game somewhat live.

The other thing is that the visuals are very, very outdated.  again, this is an almost 3 decade old game, but in my opinion it has stood the test of time.

before you play the game, be aware the programs that come with the game are outdated and may not fuction properly on a modern OS.  You should download Darkplaces, which is a modern engine for Quake.  unzip the files into the directory of this game and just run Darkplaces.   Better yet, there is an ultimate Quake Patch you can download as well.  

http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1756923

28475650.review:
This was one of the earlier First-Person Shooters I played growing up. It's a decent game, but shows its age in its gameplay.

PROS
+Mechanically sound. Gunplay works accurately, and is one of the first FPS games where being able to look up and down is more than useful: it's necessary.
+Wide variety of difficult enemies to kill, from lethal Ogres to tanky Death Knights to Zombies that just won't stay down.
+Among the first games to incorperate jumping and swimming well.
+Instead of being openly demonic, game takes more of a gothic approach with only one monster that's clearly a demon instead of a monster.
+Greatly atmospheric, with cold, dark, and slimy level designs.
+Added some mechanics which have become a staple of arcade FPS games ever since (such as rocket jumping, bunny hopping, and changing the direction of your jump midair).
+Paved the way for many mods which would turn into their own games (such as Team Fortress)
+Includes support for OpenGL which really helps the graphical quality.

CONS:
-Weapons work differently, which is initially confusing. Shotguns are similar to Doom or Duke Nukem, with an instant hit/miss with each pull of the trigger. Machineguns (called Nail Guns in game) fire slow-moving projectiles, which require more leadtime to be useful.
-Some levels are confusing and frustrating to advance in.
-Console commands necesary to enable mouse look every time you load the game, something which (I would think) be able to switch on and leave on.

It's fine, and I had fun playing it, but be aware that it's very much a product of the times, and it shows in more ways than the graphics.

27833406.review:
Quake is one of those games that, despite its flaws, has stood the test of time like few others. id made an incredible job of using their limitations to their advantage. The combat is much more close quarters than his cousin Doom due to polycount restrictions, resulting in a much more oppresive experience and tactical interplay between enemy and level design that keeps the game varied without any need for character progression. The monochrome palette flourishes in its lower Middle Age / Lovecraftian setting, evoking a sense of gloom and pestilence that never allows you to be comfortable in any place. Even the dated visuals add to a sense of charm.

Do not miss the chance to play it up to decent current standards with the Quakespasm/Fitzquake engine, and great mods like Arcane Dimensions.

PROS: A precious blend of atmosphere and fast-paced combat and pure unadulterated fun, stuffed with secrets and power-ups in the best 1990s game tradition.

CONS: The mouse controls are the part that has stood worst the test of time, and would really benefit from a revamp (can be modded though). If you can't use 3D acceleration, the highest resolutions run the game at truly unplayable framerates.

8/10

Buy it whether you played in its day or not, for a timeless piece of History.

If one game needs a Doom-like reboot by id Software, is this one.

27757129.review:
I do still remember the very first time I played Quake; I liked it from the beginning: the visuals, colours, sound effects, and then, the music. I never knew the music and sound effectes were composed by Trent Reznor until I actually got the game and began playing and noticed that ammo box with the NIN logo.

  Quake still absolutely stands up today. Its visuals might be pixellated, the environments often rather monochrome, as became the running gag, yet the design of the world is admirable, the levels balanced, structured and well paced. The variety on display, despite the vast swathes of brown, dwarfs that of most modern games as well. This game itself wrote into its story a great way of swinging between science fiction and grim medieval fantasy: set the game in the future, and have it be about a dude travelling through flashy, high-tech slipgate complexes into an alternate dimension where everything’s grand but grimy, and apparently six centuries old.

  The weapons pack a punch, though, which is a good thing. While Quake’s 3D engine meant it could never pack quite as many enemies on-screen as its spiritual predecessor, Doom, those who are present are a tough collective. The Vores, for example (arachnoid beasts firing heat-seeking spike balls from their bellies) take an absolute age to bring down, not to mention a rucksack full of rockets. And the sheer breathtaking speed of the Fiends, all claws and jaws and nightmare, means that hitting them before they scratch your eyes out is a genuinely finger-destroying task.

  Those are just a few of the reasons why I do still like Quake a lot today, after 20 years.

27695925.review:
Quake and Quakeworld is the game that holds dearest to my heart, of any game ever.
It's the game that got me into PC gaming, the community was small back then compared to today but the people who played it were passionate, obsessive and very competetive. But those people were a very tight family, a real community with a wonderful spirit  comradery. I've never come accross such a passionate group of people since and nor do I think I will in the future. Back then we had very little in terms of cutting edge hardware, we had 56k modems and Pentium II (if you were flash) with 32 MEGS! of RAM. You had to do the homework, write the scripts and binds, eek every last little bit out of your connection, the list goes on. Names like Sujoy, Clan 9 and Lakerman will only mean something to the few who were there at the time and I'd go back there in an instand just for one more game with those folks. But that day is gone in the name of progress, but the memories will last literally a lifetime.
And remember kids THIS is where rocket jumping started, FACT!

OK this time this one is for the STEAM AWARDS.

I played Quake 1 in 2002 for the first time, and it's still a great first person shooter in all time.
Quake is fast, wild, speedy, furious, goreness, bloody, dark, crazy, incrediblely fun. And Quake requires raw skills to beat. It's one of the kings of the thrones of the early 3D FPSes among with Unreal which make your dizzy, vomitting, adrenined. It makes the weak want to quit the PvP electronical sports until years later they can play Counter Strike or Call of Duty. It makes your little sister and brother admire you more. It makes your future son never dare to challenge your FPS domination. It makes your parents hate video games brainlessly. It makes your schoolmates stun and your old Pentium II 450MHz processor with Voodoo 2 graphics card burning besides the crying of your Microsoft mice. It makes you a special person who has the balls to tell the differences of different monitors which support 120Hz or 144Hz refresh rate between 60, 90, 120, 180 framerates. It make you seem like to be a insider of Ang Lee's Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk at its best of 4K resolution with 120fps. And after all, it makes you never be afraid of any 3D sickness and years later laughing and having fun in Virtual Reality while the others can only play just minutes.

If human race will vanish, and there is only one FPS game can be saved. I will recommend Quake along with the sound tracks made by Trent Reznor and Nine Inch Nails.

I don't play much Quake on Steam, mostly on an old copy I get from retail with GLQuake executables. New community mods make old Quake so fresh and shinny that almost a modern game with incredible lightening and shadow effects. Still a bad-ass.

I would recommend Quake to anyone who's interested in first person shooter.

27058448.review:
I've been meaning to write this review earlier, but I know that no one in the world knows about this game.  Now with the achievements, I have an excuse to finally write this!

Quake is id Software's first foray into a true 3D game, a first person shooter in the vein of Doom.  During it's debut, it was groundbreaking for its technological advancements, and is now well known for being the basis of some of video game's biggest hits, where they originally branched out of a Quake mod.

Most remember it for its multiplayer, but few talk about how its single player campaign holds up.  Admittedly, the story is very anachronistic and shoehorned due to it being based off of an earlier build; Quake was slated to be an RPG in a dark fantasy world before id decided to turn it into an FPS, which is why you'll see a blend of futuristic weaponry mixed in with medieval backdrops and Lovecraftian-inspired monsters.  A lot of people will dismiss the graphics for running the "Real is Brown" trope to the ground, but I personally love it.  It adds to the atmosphere of the game along with the ambient music (wonderfully crafted by NiN) and truly lets you feel like you're alone in a desolate dimension.

The gameplay is where it truly shines.  While it was always marketed for its (at the time) amazing visuals, not a lot of people payed heed to its amazing gunplay and well-crafted difficulty.  While the original game suffers from lack of customization, source ports more than help to enhance the overall experience.  The controls really feel tight and responsive, with the gunplay rivalling modern-era games with how all the guns have a real sort of "punch" to them (the Super Nailgun in particular is absolutely cathartic).  The difficulty is also very tough, but fair.  While it still falls under the usual usage of "higher difficulty = enemies do more damage and you do less", it isn't exaggerated like in a lot of other games.  I, myself, found the highest difficulty to be a good challenge.

In all, I'd say this game has aged fairly well.  Whether it be my nostalgia goggles or not, I feel like the muddy graphics enhance the overall feel of the game's otherworldly tone.  The gameplay is as excellent as ever, and the sound design is truly phenomenal.  

If you're a fan of FPS games and you're looking for another classic to play, I'd recommend this title to you, as well as the expansion packs with it.  While the multiplayer's pretty much dead (at least to my knowledge), it's worth it if only for the single player.

26826791.review:
Ah, Quake...how much we, the gamers of the 21st century owe thee So much of the technology and so many of the conventions we now take for granted were developed for this game. So many great games were built within the Quake engine or its immediate derivatives. It is truly a landmark of gaming history. Some of the greatest geniusus of game development history invested their talents into this game and changed the industry forever.

But that's not why you should buy Quake. You should buy this game because it is still one of the best shooters ever made. It's stilll scary and exciting in equal measure. Its design is still darkly original, it's arsenal still finely balanced, and its gameplay still wickely slick.

Once you are done with the ~9 hour campaign, why not check out the multiplayer that remains active more than twenty years after the game's release (if that's not proof enough of Quake's superiority, then nothing is). Or perhaps you could head over to Quaddicted.com and try any one of the 1200 user-made single player maps and map packs.

For two decades Quake has been an unexhaustable source of pleasure for gamers and I full expect to still be basking in its glory twenty years hence.

26429051.review:
Legendary game. One of the most satisfying shooters ever and the birth of online gaming. Very atmospheric and creepy at times thanks to the great soundtrack by Trent Reznor (Nine Inch Nails) which Steam does NOT provide. You can download it [url=https://www.quaddicted.com/files/music/quake_campaign_soundtrack.zip]here[/url] and use a source port that will play and loop the music files as intended.

20 years later the community continues to create impressive, high quality content (single player maps) which will give you hundreds of additional hours of gameplay. No HD patches needed; Quake aged like a fine wine and looks great in all its glorious square pixels at 1080p. Just skim through my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/daxbutane/screenshots/?appid=2310]screenshots[/url] and see for yourself.

There's nothing quite like Quake. Every fan of the FPS genre should play it at least once.

26256158.review:
- Note that I've played at least 10 hours via a launcher that doesn't add to Steam playtime -

I never played the original Quake until I got it this year so I don't have the whole nostalgia thing but even so this is it, when action games had effort put into actually making them fun and engaging with actual areas to explore and decisions to make before becoming more about hand-holding and empty spectacle.

There's some weird stuff like the Super Shotgun and Nailgun just being flat upgrades of the non-supers and hit detection with some enemy attacks being a bit off, but...that's kind of it. Sure it's simple but everything works so well. This is a damn good shooter far better than most despite being two decades old now. The age sort of works to its advantage in a way, it can run on just about anything, there's a good number of levels in the main game and a history of loads of mods and maps, with people making more even today. Machine Games who did the awesome Wolfenstein reboot actually made a free level pack recently which is pretty kickass.

Every fan of action games, especially those who've mostly only played recent ones should play this.

25828722.review:
Mannnnnnnn what do I even say? I was raised an id kid. I remember being in the single digits and sitting in a chair next to my Mom and Dad, watching them play Wolfenstein/Doom/Doom2. I was too scared to actually play it myself then, it took me awhile to work up the courage to try it myself, but when I finally did...the rest is history. We played and replayed those early id games for years, and then finally Quake came out. My parents weren't into the transition into 3d, but me, I saw the future in this game, it is responsible for so much.

In my eyes, Quake 1 still remains the most excellent FPS you could ever hope to play. ESPECIALLY the multiplayer. I still think Quake 1 far outweighs even the might Quake 3 in simplicity and fun factor. It's just so damn fun and adrenaline-pumping to play, even now. I'm still addicted, even now, after all these years....

So in modern reviewing format:

Quake gets 420 no-scopes out of 10.

24706321.review:
[h1][b]Quake				* 7/10[/b][/h1]

A game that represented a historical turning point for gaming.

Quake is an FPS from iD software that followed Doom II. Its importance is mostly due to the technical evolution at the time of its release. Available both in software renderer and OpenGL renderer it allowed real 3d environments, items and enemies, advanced architecture (overlying floors, floating lifts, moving surfaces or floors...). Nowadays we take this for granted but for the time it was a real revolution especially the GL version that allowed a smoother graphic and a superior performance.

Nowadays Quake's engine looks pretty old, with very low polys models and undefined blurry textures. Yet even nowadays there are many ports available with texture packs, improved renders and effects that allow to play this old classic with a 16:9 high resolution giving a great (and resource demanding) aesthetic experience, even though the game is over 20 years old.

I wasn't forced to use those ports as the game luckily runs both with software and OpenGL render On my machine but the graphics is so old that I had to use an updated port to play (Personally I've used Darkplaces, you can see pictures in my galleries).

Music score was composed by Trent Reznor from Nine Inch Nails and is made of environmental and instrumental quite heavy tracks. Unfortunately once again there's no soundtrack available in this steam release for no logical reason, luckily with ports and updates there are also packages available in the web that includes the full soundtrack for both the game and the expansions.

Story is almost inexistent as in most old iD games, it's more like a context: You are a soldier or better, Ranger that has to save the earth from an alien, codename Quake, and his army that moves to places with portals named "Slipgates".

What's more important then the story is the game's art, heavily inspired by medieval themes, so you will be exploring many locations with typical elements such as rose windows, mosaics, churches, castles, libraries, drawbridges. Even some enemies are knights with swords. Still this is an FPS so you have shotguns, chainguns (converted to nailguns, who knows why), rocket launchers and there are also enemies with chainguns, grenade launchers, ghosts, zombies, so this is not an accurate medieval reproduction but mostly just an artistic choice. 

[h1]+++PROs+++[/h1][list]
[*][b] FPS.[/b] This is the good old classic frantic FPS, with loads of enemies, weapons, secrets and more. Just run and shoot everything that moves and go ahead. Simple and fun.
[/list]
[h1]---CONs---[/h1][list]
[*][b] OLD.[/b] Quake is 20 years old as I'm writing and its age is really a visible issue. Even in GL Render models have a really low polycount and textures are barely detailed, not to mention the lack of mouselook support or 16:9 display compatibility. Luckily there are updated ports that can MASSIVELY improve the experience with new effects, lighting, textures pack, and new models (I've used Darkplaces, you can see pictures in my galleries).
[*][b] STEAM RELEASE.[/b] Even though there are no relevant compatibility issues, once again there's no music in this release (Same problem as in Quake 2). Luckily there are patches that bring it back both in Vanilla and Any other port release.
[/list]

[i]I played this game on this machine:
Laptop Lenovo Z50
Intel Core i5-4210U
8Gb RAM DDR3
GeForce 840M/Intel HD Graphics 4400
Windows 10 Home x64[/i]

24653837.review:
The first-person shooter genre is built on the backs of giants, and few are as big as the Quake series. It was the first fully-3D shooter success story and helped kick the online multiplayer scene into overdrive. We're a long way out from the golden age of iD Software, but their titles have incredible staying power thanks to solid fundamentals and vibrant modding scenes. The original Quake is no exception, but as I'll explain, you may want to consider your options before picking up this particular version.

Quake technically has a plot, but it was literally one type-written page in the jewelcase-insert manual. Government makes portal thingies, demon thingies come out of portals, you kill demons with gun thingies. In practice this means four episodes of gruesome treks into ruined bases, medieval castles, nonsensical hellmazes, and twisting eldritch architecture. There are a lot of elements to laud about Quake but the one I'm really going to harp on is the feel of it, because it's one of the best cosmic horror FPSes to date outside of the literal Lovecraftian ones like Call of Cthulhu and Eldritch. Levels are tightly-designed labyrinths of decaying arches and gothic spires, impossible woodwork and ageless caverns. The modeling detail and texture work really drives home the atmosphere of ancient, neglected places full of unspeakable things, and the dated, chunky graphics actually help the unearthly feel.

Then of course there are the unspeakable things trying to kill you. Quake features a refreshingly diverse cast of beings to forcibly disassemble, from corrupted marines to bloodthirsty knights, self-dismembering zombies to spider-legged horrors. The key here is that they cover the standard enemy roles in unusual ways, the Ogre being the prime example of this. One of the most common enemies in the game, he's armed with a heavily-damaging grenade launcher and an even nastier chainsaw. This wouldn't really fly in a lot of games, but the combination of high movespeed and effective weapon variety means you'll always have options in combating him and avoiding his brutal damage entirely.

It's these player elements that make Quake feel like a bridge between Doom and the modern era. You avatar still darts around levels at inhuman speeds, allowing you to weave between foes to spark infighting or bait melee attacks. Your freedom of movement also lets you seek out the many secrets of every level, often hidden in ingenious ways. The weapons are a good spread of utility but without any real stand-outs like the BFG of old, giving you an effective if not exciting arsenal to dispatch your enemies with. There are some creative interactions, at least, like zombies only being killable with explosives, or the lightning gun killing you (and everything else) if used underwater.

The ironclad fundamentals of Quake make it a timeless classic that still holds up to this day, even discounting the incredible multiplayer or soundtrack (an original Trent Reznor creation!). And you will need to discount those if you pick this version up, because they're not included. The Steam version of Quake lacks the CD soundtrack, and features four outdated executables for the game. Two of these are old Quakeworld multiplayer-only clients that are now defunct. The other two are ancient versions of winQuake designed for Win95 that may not run on your system at all. The unfortunate truth is that Quake might not work for you at all out of the proverbial box. There are plenty of source ports that WILL work if you download them, as long as you own the official game, but understand that modding may be your only option to enjoy what you're buying.

In the end, what I'm saying here is that you should own Quake and you should play Quake, but this version isn't necessarily the best way to do that. A retro-friendly storefront like GOG is more likely to have one that will play without any fiddling, but all the same you should be prepared to mod Quake if you want the most out of it. I don't normally speak of modding in my reviews but this is one of the rare times it's a necessity, especially if you want to dip your toes in the multiplayer. I assure the hassle is worth it, because Quake formed the foundation of FPSes for good reason, and even now it's a unique and thrilling experience.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

24531119.review: Quake is everything that the fans of the series claimed it would be. Quake follows the ranger (the protagonist) as he goes about collecting the 4 legendary runes in order to stop the Shub-Niggurath. The theme of interdimensional beings invading Earth seemed to be a popular theme among the time. The game is split into 4 episodes and the final boss fight. You can access any episode from the hub which has a great layout that I really enjoyed. Each episode is a decent length with around 7 or 8 levels, and the levels themselves usually have a few puzzles in order to keep you from just speed running it like in the DOOM franchise. The movement is fast paced allowing for you to easily out maneuver your opponent, while also keeping things from getting stale. The weapons in Quake are all unique in their own way some more useful than others. The enemies of Quake seem to share an eldritch horror style and are each unique with some requiring certain weapons to defeat them. The graphics in Quake invoke a nostalgic feel but are also heavily outdated. I did not play the multiplayer as I am sure that there are few servers if any at all still running. Quake does everything right that I wanted from a game like Doom and I had a fun time going through the story and playing through this gem of a game.

Прошел  я наконец-то таки первый Квак и приобщился, так сказать, к прекрасному.
Что же игра из себя представляет? Тот же спинномозговой боевик от 1-го лица от ID и Ко. Буду называть плюсы игры, сравнивая игру иногда с DOOMом:
+ Как всегда отличная атмосфера и сеттинг - готичные замки, церкви и прочие аббатства и катакомбы при прохождении прилагаются.
+ Интересный сет врагов: рыцари с мечами, мужики с безопилами и гранотометами в руках, летающие мумии с хвостами, какие-то прыгающие огры и огромные монстры-мутанты дети Шуб-Ниггуратта, а также Солдаты-зомби и просто собачки.
+ Динамика по сравнению с DOOM возросла до космических масштабов. Носимся и мечемся по уровню в разные стороны и поливаем всё живое из своего Гвоздемёта.
+ НОРМАЛЬНАЯ планировка уровней. В Думе уровни представляли из себя раскуроченное нечто: кучу комнат, где в 95% надо было включать тонну рубильников и искать сине-желто-красные ключи для открытия дверей. Здесь же такого нет. Ну как нет, есть, но не в таких промышленных масштабах, как это было в 1 и 2 Думе. Да и сами левела стали чутка линейней и порой заблудиться в них становиться очень сложно (то есть особо не заблудитесь).
+ ПОЛНОЦЕННОЕ 3-ДЭ же :) (Представте людей в 1996 году, которые увидели первый Квак и и при этом полностью ТРЕХМЕРНЫЙ. Не иначе как кипятком ссались наверное при виде сего чуда :))
+ Расчлененка врагов.
+ Великолепныя музыка, которая по умолчанию выпилена из игры, поэтому придёться скачать и установить патч, который эту самую музыку возвращает в игру.
+ Божественный саунд подбора 25 хелсовой аптечки. Нет, ну правда, меня прям доставил звук подбора аптечки :) 
+ Безбашенный геймплей: куча крови, кишок, расчлененного мяса и кровавого фарша, а также тонны пуль, гранат, гвоздей и дроби летящие во врагов из ваших стволов и при всем при этом вы ещё скачите и носитесь по уровню как оглашенный. ВОСХИТЕЛЬНО, что ещё сказать.
Итог: ЛЕГЕНДА! Поиграть стоит всем, кто неравнодушен к тупым, бестолковым и бессмыслено-беспощадным шутанам-боевикам от первого лица с бешенной динамикой перестрелок и бега.

Легендарный шутер с мрачной атмосферой. Хотя оружие не столь оригинальное (два дробовика, два гвоздомёта, два гранатомёта, тундерболт и топор), но разнообразие противников и интересный дизайн уровней заставляют менять свою тактику на лету.

Уровни сложности меняют не урон и здоровье монстров, а (как и в старых Думах) количество и вид монстров, что, на мой взгляд, интереснее. Шэмблеры до сих вызывают ужас. Можно даже сказать, что Quake - это шутер с элементами хоррора, как DOOM 3.

An absolutely fantastic game with smooth gameplay despite it`s age. The overall design and atmosphere within the game is astounding and can be genuinely frightening if played on higher difficulty settings such as nightmare, not through arbitrary and scripted sequences, but through the enemy design and gameplay. HOWEVER, I must stress that despite this, a newer sourceport such as quakespasm or darkspaces is recommended due to the original engine not having aged too well.I personally recommend Darkplaces due to it`s compatibility and options such as FOV sliders and customisable lighting and effects, allowing you to give the game some visual upgrades.
The weapons all serve great purpose and some damage enemies better than others, combined with the unique behaviour of each, the player is left with a game of great challenge and intrigue. The game features a well composed soundtrack by Nine inch nails and their logo can be seen on ammunition containers throughout.
While the game is definitely not perfect, it is a game that any oldschooler would be incredibly comfortable with, however newschool players may find it less.
Overall a solid gold piece of the past, not for everyone but for me, it was a good time.

24231526.review:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Quake ist einer der Klassiker der Ego-Shooter Geschichte aus dem Jahre 1996.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Man Spielt einen Überlebenden aus einer Forschungsbasis die mit Portalen in andere Welten experimentiert. Man hat sich zur Aufgabe gemacht alle Portale zu schlissen, es sind Vier Episoden mit insgesamt 32 Leveln. Man sucht Schlüssel, Schalter, löst diverse Rätsel und tötet die Monster um zum Ende zu jedes Levels kommen. Die Gegner haben eine sehr unterschiedliche Ki und jeder Gegner hat so seine Eigenheiten sodass es nicht langweilig wird. Zum Anfang gibt es Drei verschiedene Schwierigkeitsgrade zur Auswahl die das Spiel sehr fordernd machen.

Quake Mission Pack I: Scourge of Armagon:

Eine Weiterführung der Geschichte von Quake, spielerisch Identisch nur ein sind neue 4 neue Gegner, 4 neue Waffen, 3 neue PowerUps und neue Musik dazu gekommen.

Quake Mission Pack II: Dissolution of Eternity:

Eine Weiterführung der Geschichte von Quake, spielerisch Identisch nur ein sind neue 14 neue Gegner, 4 neue Waffen, 3 neue PowerUps und neue Musik dazu gekommen. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mehrspieler: 

Der Mehrspieler Modus ist noch im Kleinen kreisen aktiv, man kann aber mit verschieden Mods z.B Dark Places sehr einfach noch aktive Server finden.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grafik:

Die Grafik ist immer noch sehr schön anzusehen, dennoch Rate ich wieder zum modden da man so ganz individuell seine Grafik Vorlieben nehmen kann.

(Ich habe z.B. Grafikstil Original und bessere Lichteffekte, höhere Auflösung und anderen kleinen schnick-schnack)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik ist bei der Steam Version nicht vorhanden und muss manuell runtergeladen und eingefügt werden.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=119489135

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung Super, hatte keinerlei Probleme es mit Maus und Tastatur zu spielen. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ gute Grafik
+ sehr gute Steuerung
+ viele Secrets
+ einfach Moddbar und sehr viele Mods
- Soundtrack nicht vorhanden in der Steam Version

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Einer der besten Shooter der sehr gut gewaltet ist durch die Community Mods. Ich habe Quake früher immer gerne als Kind gespielt, und bis heute ist es wirklich genial die verschiedenen Gegner und ihr Eigenheiten, der grosse und Übersichtliche Level Aufbau und die vielen Secrets. Das Beste an Quake ist das man es schnell Spielen kann und langsam, aber diese Spielgeschwindigkeit ist nur bei alten ID Games zu finden und nicht bei den meisten neuen Shootern. Ich habe 5h auf Einfach mit ein Paar Secrets und hängern gebraucht. Wer also für 4,99€ oder es mal im Angebot kauf wird sicherlich nicht enttäuscht.

Die beiden Addons sind schon ganz gut gemacht kein 08/15 DLC Mist aber einzeln hätte ich sie nicht gekauft. Aber wenn man sich die Quake Collection kauft ist es vollkommen OK.

Ich rate sowieso jedem sich die Quake Collection Giften zu lassen
wenn sie mal um 75% Reduziert (5,75€) ist und 
Quake IV (Retail) als Key (für circa 7€) beim Keyseller im Angebot zu kaufen
und Quake Live wenn sie mal um 75% Reduziert (2,50€) ist.

Mehr als 15€ habe ich nicht bezahlt für 5 geile Games und 5 Addons die immer recht gut sind.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Zusammengefasst: 

Einzelspieler: 10/10
Mehrspieler: 3/10
Grafik: 9/10
Musik: 7/10
Steuerung: 10/10
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Spiel: 8/10

24045742.review:
[h1] Played on Darkplaces Sourceport via Ultimate Quake patch [/h1]


[u] A DISCLAIMER [/u]
Everything you are about to read is entirely my opinion, proceed with caution. Now, before an angry mob comes and chews me out. Just hear me out, alright? 

[h1] My Thoughts [/h1]

I [b] personally [/b] (as some may agree) think that Doom was a much more enjoyble experience than this. But that doesn't take away anything from Quake itself, the game is great, fast paced, definitely set the standards for the FPS games we have today, as well as introducing tricks such as b-hopping, rocket jumping, etc. Without Quake, there would be no Half-Life, without Half-Life, there'd be no Counter-Strike and so on, you get the picture. Quake was also id Software's first full fledged 3D game, everything is fully modeled. From the maps, to weapon models, and to enemies. Definitely a step up in a technical standpoint compared to Doom, kudos to John Romero and John Carmack. 

I appreciate what Quake is, and what id Software was going for. A kind of gothic sci-fi shooter that's episode based, much like the style of Wolfenstien and Doom. Only except you choose your skill level, and episodes in game by walking through portals, "slipgates" to be more precise. There are 8 regular maps in each episode, again like Doom. The soundtrack however...is meh to me, it's not bad. But it's nowhere near as memorable as Doom's, the only track I remember from Quake is the menu theme, all the other tracks are just ambience that only fit when listened in game. Surprisingly enough, the soundtrack was made noneother by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails. (Who happened to be a huge fan of Doom might I add), but it's just kinda strange to me how none of the other tracks really just stick to me, you know? Considering NIN puts out some really good music.

[h1] The Plot [/h1]

Wait what? You can't be serious, you're not playing id's games for the story, are you? Ok, well the plot is very minimal. You're a guy named Ranger, you kill stuff, you travel to different dimensions, and you kill stuff and collect runes at the end of each episode, where small plot is given through text, [i] again [/i] like Wolfenstein and Doom.

[h1] The Enemies You'll Face [/h1]

In my experience, the enemies also seem to both lack, but at the same time have variety to them, you have the standard former humans you encounter in the beginning of each episode (a la the zombiemen and shotgun guys in Doom), then later you fight these demonic kind of enemies. Most common enemy you'll face mid to late game is the Ogre, which use a grenade launcher in one hand, and a chainsaw in the other, fairly easy to kill, just shoot at it until it's dead.

Though, the one enemy that stands out the most to me would have to be the Zombies, you think giving them the good old one-two with the super shotgun will kill them? Think again, they're a lot more resilient than you think. You'll have to launch a grenade at them, or maybe jam a rocket in their mouth to make 'em rest in pieces. 

Now I know what you're thinking: "Oh, but Mr. Dude Man Guy, what about the Shambler?!" yes, yes. Calm down, I was just going to get to him, it, whatever. Basically this thing is the absolute most putrid offspring between the Arch-Vile, Cyberdemon, and maybe a bit of the Baron of Hell, it's very tanky (like the aforementioned Cyberdemon). It has an attack that is based on line of sight, as long as you break it, you should be fine. It also has a very strong melee attack, like the Baron's. Truly a challenge to take on.

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]

Quake itself is a great game, pioneer of the FPS genre, I'd recommend this to about anyone who's willing to go back to the roots of FPS gaming (ofc Wolfenstein mainly popularized it due to its success if you want to go deeper). But seriously, it's worth the money, I'd pick it up, especially during a sale.

P.S. Easiest way to kill the shambler? Follow this very easy step [spoiler] shoot at it until it dies [/spoiler]

24007946.review:
Created on the heels of the runaway success of the Doom series, Quake paved the way for the first-person shooter with its fast-paced action and graphical advancements. Fully realized 3D graphics resulted in some of the most intricate and well-designed maps in the genre's history. The feeling of running around the various honeycombed shortcuts is an unmatched satisfaction in FPS movement. Each map is made eye-catching and memorable by the game's distinct artstyle which draws from a fusion of medieval and metallic. The same can be said for the game's enemy roster, which range from laser rifle-lugging shock troopers to muscle-bound bundles of teeth and claws. Unfortunately the base game doesn't take full advantage of the diversity of its enemies, with later levels sinking into the tedium of firing shotgun shell after shotgun shell into ogres and death-knights. This is rectified somewhat by the higher difficulties, which see no problem in pitting unrealistic numbers against the player. Quake is an addicting and wonderful game at any price, and it's worth owning to understand what makes this game such a solid pillar of the genre. Now let's hope they don't give this an ill-fitting modern reboot as well...

If you want to improve your experience check out some of the community guides on how to implement things like different engines and the soundtrack. The base Steam release is unfortunately lacking in some areas, and the work getting in fixes can be well worth the effort.

23912729.review:
Do you like/play videogames?
Do you like/play First Person Shooters?

If the answer to any of those questions is "Yes" then PLAY THIS GAME

QUAKE FREAKING RULES: It is simultaneously the most important PC videogame to ever be released aside from Unreal and Doom, and at the same time one of the most pulse pounding, erection throbbing, masculine pieces of hardcore videogaming to be ever devised.  If you haven't played this game, you can't call yourself a lover of videogames.

The story is.... Well WHO GIVES A HORSE?? But in case you want to know what's going on:
You are Ranger: A warrior of earth who is sent by the leaders of earth through these ancient portals (Called Slipgates) into other dimentions to retrieve 4 runes and stop the evil overlord Shub-Niggurath that is controlling all the monsters that you fight. The whole story is told through the level design, and from the text and the end of each episode, just to make sure you haven't ran away to burn down your school.

The art style is very reminisent of Gothic, Sci-fi, Hell, and the Occult. The whole art style feels like a love letter to the powerful H.P. Lovecraft (if you don't know him, get out and read Cthulu).  Playing Quake feels like being trapped in a metal band's nightmare of awesomness. It's dark, gritty, terrifying, and it just feels wrong. but plays so right. And it should feel like a metal band's nightmare, because Trent Reznor of the band Nine Inch Nails helped ID Software create this masterpiece. He did the amazing music, some of the iconic sound effects, and the voice of Ranger.

The level design is SECOND TO NONE: This is as criptic as Doom, and every single map is carefully constructed and planned so that you feel overwhelmed on where you need to go, yet they are simple enough to navigate so that you get the feeling of being a baddass, overcoming the criptic levels. The sheer amount of effort and detail that went into these levels puts every single fps level made today to shame. Even Doom 2016's levels, while criptic and challenging, are childs play compared to the epicness of Quake. The only other games I can think of that have better level design that this are Doom 1 & 2, Heretic/Hexen, Blood, Duke Nukem 3D, and Unreal 1. And even then, I would say that Quake is more complex and better than all of them: the levels are not as straightforward as Dooms, nor as brainkilling as Heretic/Hexens, nor as believable or iconic as Blood or Duke Nukem 3D's; Quake's levels feel like something out of a nightmare and there has been nothing like this ever been seen since.

The music in Quake is just simply amazing. It captures the whole mood of being in a nightmare, and is as iconic as Quake it'self. Just listen to this, and it sums up what playing quake is like:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mv5Jvr2Fp48

The enemies are amazing and very original too: You have to learn and memorise all their attack patterns and behaviours to overcome them, and use the right weapon for the right enemy.

The weapons themselves are also metal as fuck: You start off with Ranger's iconic [strike]useless[/strike] Axe, and a fast firing shotgun. There is then the Double barrel shotgun, and the rocket launcher, all stuff you expect. Instead of a machine gun, you have NAILGUNS: a Double barrel nailgun, and a Gattling nail gun, and the nails are not hitscan attacks they are projectiles, so you have to lead your targets. You also get a grenade launcher and a rocket launcher to kill the undead zombies, as they can only be killed by Gibbing them. Finally you have the lightning gun, which requires you to have a line of sight on your enemies to use, so you can't simply use it and duck behind a pillar, meaning you have to THINK on how you will use it.

And did I mention this game is hard? FREAKING hard? Even on the easiest difficulty this game will test your skills to the bone. In fact the Nightmare difficulty is so hard that they hid it in the episode select hub. See if you can find it and takkle the ultimate challenge.

This is also one of the most important PC games ever made: It was one of the first games to use 3D polygons and run itself off a computers CPU, which was mindboggling for the year 1997. It was the first FPS game to implement the WASD+Mouse controls as standard for FPS, it cemented the fast paced arena deathmatch multiplayer, and it's mindblowing idTech graphics engine created a game engine for HUNDREDS of games to use. So many iconic games today have used this game's engine; Call of Duty, Half-Life, Counter-Strike, the original Team Fortress was a mod for this, and I could go on ALL DAY.

Quake is one of the greatest videogames of all time, and the aftershock of it's impact and legecy are STILL being felt to this day. Quake changed videgames forever. 

5/5 An unmissable masterpiece.

Still not convinced? Watch this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OipJYWhMi3k

[Editors note: If you want to have the full experience, download this source port for the game:
Darkplaces: https://icculus.org/twilight/darkplaces/
It allows for more lighting options, has higher resolutions, and includes the music, which is absent from the steam release. Install this into your Quake folder in your Steamapps directory file, and you should be good to go!]

23909604.review:
Quake: The great-grandaddy of 3D/FPS, son of Doom and Heretic, son of Wolfenstein-3D (1992) and Stellar 7 -- The beauty of Quake is that is was the first bona-fide 3D 'engine' in commercial PC games. 

Releasing the original Quake engine to the dev community was the move that later inspired Valve Software's Gabe Newell to release their own engine-dev environment, "Source", owing to the first Half-Life game being built upon a modified Quake 3D engine. (dubbed "GoldSrc")

Quake is easily one of the most significant, if not enjoyable, shooters of all time, with hundreds of different mods (including the original Team Fortress) and is still supported by a rabid fan base. 

Without Quake, PC gaming would not be what it is today.
