17273024.review:
This game still stands as a unique, abstract shooter with a thickly-dark atmosphere.   No storyline; just a series of demonic mazes and fast action.  I lost much of my youth caught up in the multiplayer aspect of this game.  Gameplay-wise, it's a  basic but smooth formula.  It offers a challenge that is purely skill based; not just on your aim; but your timing, prediction and almost gymnastic movement around the levels.

I still think it's a technical marvel.  This was one of the first full-3D games; and the levels are deliberately vertical and abstract in their design.  Everything has long since been open sourced; as a coder it's intriguing to inspect the design from a kind of archeological perspective.

When starting, you're given the option to choose which executable to run;  QuakeWorld (which was its brilliant online version - though surely not noob friendly), didn't work for me.   Perhaps with some technical tinkering you can get this to work.  (It was never straightforward back in the day anyway)

I've tested the GLQuake option, is the hardware rendering option, this works without any issues.  I'm sure there are mods out there that improve the experience, though.

Gamers today will probably never feel the same sense of awe and wonder and compelling multiplayer gameplay as we did when it released.  I'm kinda glad that games have moved on though, this game has a slightly discomforting pull, like it's almost half-living, a demon demanding my return.   As a skeptical atheist, it's beyond disturbing.

My time with this game is done;  it was a strange friend that was always present, but I hardly miss.  It still quietly haunts my subconscious to this day.   Damn.

17233739.review:
The game itself gets all thumbs up, it's a true classic and one of the best games of all time. You don't get this sort of frenzied action and complex level design anymore, and it's wonderfully dark and gloomy.

The soundtrack, made by Nine Inch Nails in the Downward Spiral era, is absolutely fantastic, one of the best soundtracks of all time, incredibly dark and eerie. The graphics look outdated to say the least, but that CD soundtrack didn't age a day, quite the contrary. Alone, the game's darkness can't really impress anymore, but with the soundtrack it really comes to life.

And there's the problem. This Steam version comes without the soundtrack. It doesn't even have any. Selling Quake without its epic soundtrack is ridiculous, because it's such an important part of it. I haven't seen any well visible warning on the store page that informs you about this, so it's borderline fraud.

There seem to be workarounds if you are willing to download it from the internet (probably illegal). But the as-is version sold here gets a BIG thumbs down.

17229585.review:
(I played this through Darkplaces so my hours will not show up on here.) 

Quake is one of the best FPS games I have ever played. The setting and weapons were just so unique. The soundtrack is absolutly superb and was composed by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails. Quake's story and gameplay is very similar to DOOM's except this was created in a true 3D engine. IMPORTANT: As of right now the soundtrack does not work with the Steam version so if your not willing to fiddle with a Source Port and some audio downloads your going to be out of luck as far as music is concerned. The game is very Lovecraftian themed (Cthulhu, etc). You'll encounter demonic knights with swords, strange creatures of all shapes and sizes, zombified soldiers, and THE SHAMBLER. Quake has an episode based level design so you will go through one episode tackling a whole bunch of levels and then be put back into a hub area in order to select the next episode. There are four episodes in total. This game oozes immersion and atmosphere. You may play hours of it without notice sometimes. I would recommend this game to anyone into 90's FPS such as DOOM or Duke. This game is not just a game. It is an experience.

Eine Handlung oder gar Story braucht keiner erwarten. Einfach den Schießprügel in die Hand nehmen und sich durch die linearen Level kämpfen. Klar, auf Grund des Alters sind die Level und die Gegner nicht sehr schön. Macht nix. Für zwischendurch ist es auf jeden Fall geeignet. 

Ich empfehle auf jenden Fall auf Hard zu spielen. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad in den damaligen Spielen hat sich immer an der Gegneranzahl und nicht an irgendwelchen KI-Werten gemessen.

Eer einmal das poltern der Granaten gehört und den "Eisbären" erlegt hat, wird es so schnell nicht wieder aus der Hand geben.

PS: Tipp am Rande: Die Zombies müssen mit Explosivwaffen vernichtet werden. ;)

Do i really need to tell you how good it is ?
I won't talk about how important this game was to gaming as a whole, with it's innovative, revolutionary, previously unseen tech  and addictive, genre defining, balanced multiplayer that created a stone solid community which is still strong today, and united gamers around the globe.

9/10 one of best shooters, much, MUCH better than duke nukem 3d and/or Quake 2.

16936763.review:
The early 90s was an interesting time for the FPS genre. The game most often given the title of the original first person shooter is Wolfenstein 3D, released in May of 1992 by id Software. This FPS is extremely primitive by today's standards, consisting of mostly barren environments with many repetitive sprites, but it left a strong impression on the gaming world as being an innovative and exciting game that made you feel like you were a soldier directly killing Nazis. Only eighteen months later, in December of 1993, id Software would revolutionize the gaming world with the quintessential DOOM, a much more detailed, aggressive, and yet comedic game than id's previous game. DOOM quickly became a beloved classic and was one of the most important, if not THE most important FPS of the 90s because of its refined controls, weapon variety, unique environments, hellish setting, memorable music, comedic value, and bright, cartoonish, characteristic and instantly recognizable art style. DOOM may have been gorier and superficially darker than W3D, but the game itself was quite bright and retained a simplistic manner that was palettable to audiences worldwide. Less than a year later, id Software released DOOM 2: Hell on Earth, a stylistically very similar game to its initial DOOM release, albeit with some graphical enhancements. The setting and weapons were similar and the game maintained its predecessor's cartoonish look and feel. There weren't many noticeable differences between the original game and its sequel, save for much better multiplayer and refinements to the original game.

Then, in June 1996, id Software released Quake. This game changed nearly everything from the DOOM playstyle. The gameplay was faster. Enemies were more nightmarish and unpredictable. The game used a 3D engine so the game actually gave the player a sense of depth and weight. The setting was dark, foreboding, and more in line with horror. The light/darkness was closer to depicting reality than a cartoon. Quake marked a definitive split from earlier ventures into the FPS genre by giving the player a sense of fear, urgency, and panic. Dark, unrelenting, and frightening for the time, this game took everything comedic from the DOOM franchise (since the series was goofy, silly, and didn't take itself that seriously) and reversed it. It added an actual atmosphere and made a tonal shift from light-hearted goofiness to the grittiness of a biting underworld. 

As with DOOM and W3D, the goal of Quake is usually to find a key to open up a passage to progress in order to find another key to open up a new area to find yet another key. Yet the enemy placement, labyrinthine level design, and brutal gameplay keeps this seemingly repetitive task from becoming stale. Every section is different and you'll often have the challenge of simply figuring out where to go, what to do, and how to deal with the enemies you're faced with without dying. Sure, DOOM presented some challenges but the enemies always stood out from the environment and had simple-to-memorize patterns, and you generally had enough space to strafe to avoid enemy projectiles. Quake changed this by making the environments more confined (or feel more confined), the level design less straightforward, and enemies don't stand out as much and behave somewhat unpredictably or in ways that can be frustrating to counter. Quake is a fantastic model for how games SHOULD be made: challenging, maintaining a consistent and clear tone, requiring players to think, and never being unfair.

After Quake, id Software could never again recapture the intensity or ferocity of this gem. Quake II (1997) was, to me, a huge slap in the face, as it replaced the dark and serious tone of Quake with a silly, cartoonish, and completely out of place space marine story. In fact, the game itself was conceived as an entirely unrelated game, but because of the success of Quake, id decided to just make it a part of the series. To be honest, I never played Quake III until recently but since it was multiplayer-driven, I don't really include it as part of the series (if you want my opinion it just seems like a poor man's version of Unreal Tournament). Quake 4 was absolute trash and DOOM 3 was a major disappointment. I haven't tried id's most recent game, Rage, but I'm told it's incredibly buggy and just overall unpolished and derivative. It just goes to show not only that Quake was id Software's last great game, but that they truly lost something in their image of what their games should be like, instead going for bigger guns and more explosions and scripted events instead of heart-pounding dread and fast and furious gameplay.

This game contains something that id could never again recapture. Quake for me will always be about pure aggression, pure violence, pure intensity, and in its essence is the pure FPS. It may feel somewhat clunky nowadays (you will need to change things around in the settings if you've played any FPS's in the last 15 years), and the enemies aren't the most detailed (okay, they're downright ugly by today's standards) but in practice you will see that it is one of the most refined games, fusing fast and unforgiving gameplay with a dark and chilling atmosphere. In my personal list of top FPS games, it ranks at number 4 behind (1) Aliens versus Predator 99/Gold Edition, (2) Half-Life, and (3) Unreal Tournament.

The best word to me that sums up Quake is intense. It is a fantastic game that, while perhaps not the most innovative game of the 90s, is beyond a shadow of a doubt one of the most important. It helped to shape other FPS's to come in the late 90s, the glory years of the genre, which would come to a sad and ignominious end at the turn of the millennium.

16755308.review:
WolfensteinやDOOMをFPSの始まりだとすれば、このQuakeは現代FPSの始まり、父と言う事が出来ると思う。敵モデルは全て3Dになり、マウスで視点を上下左右自由に変更出来、Quakeの系譜、Sourceエンジンの祖父である、現代FPSの基礎は出来上がった。バニーホップが登場する初めてのゲームであり、マウスsensitivityの値などは現代のSourceエンジンとそのまま同じ値を使用できたりと、その面影は多分に現代にまで残っている。

武器とモンスターに関しては武器はショットガン系の武器はあまり強くなく、強力な華の武器ロケットランチャー、強力なライトニングで攻撃するライトニングボルト等がある。モンスターは強力な敵が多く、一定間隔で飛び掛ってくるFiend,Spawn、グレネードを発射してくるOgre、ライトニングで攻撃してくる強敵Shamblerなどがいる。リズムゲーム的な避け方を求める攻撃が多く、一見シビアだが慣れればよく見て攻撃を避ける事も出来る。

ゲーム全体のバランスに関してはDoomよりややヒットポイントの高い敵が多く、常にMAPを自由に走り回れたDOOMと比べるとやや爽快感にかける。が、そこで登場するのがQuadダメージというアイテムである。このアイテムの効果中は自分の武器のダメージがなんと四倍になる。ダメージが四倍になるので自爆ダメージには気をつけなくてはならないが、このQuadダメージを使って敵をバタバタと<<破砕>>(文字通り敵が粉々になる)していくのは実に爽快である。多少技術が必要となってしまうがQuadダメージにさらにバニーホップを加えMAPを走り回るというのは大変に爽快である。(技術を必要とせずに爽快感をうむDOOMはやはり凄い)

ちなみにバニーホップとは前進キー(W)を使わずに右キー(D)と左キー(A)とジャンプキーだけを使って素早く移動する技術の事である。FPSプレイヤーとしてはバニーホップの方法を知っていて損は無い。ここにバニーホップの方法を簡単に書いておきたいと思う。バニーホップの基本は前に書いたように前進キー(W)を使わずに右キー(D)と左キー(A)とジャンプだけで蛇行しながら前進するという事、詳しく書くと次のようになる。絶えずジャンプしながら左キーを押している間はマウスで視点を左に移動させ右キーを押している間は視点を右に移動させる。これが出来るようになるには少し練習が必要だと思う、習得したい方は練習してみてください。

またQuakeにはQuakeWorldと呼ばれるマルチプレイヤーモードがある。(coopも可能。)このQuakeWorldはいわゆるスポーツ系FPSというものの始まりであって、デスマッチ、その基本も現代とあまり変わりなくやはり既に完成している。しかし武器の威力があまりに高くシビアなゲームプレイを求められる。という点では原始的なゲームバランスと言える。

このQuakeは総合的にシングルプレイヤーモードではDoomを超える事が出来なかったと思う。が、クアッドダメージの爽快感は一度試してみる価値はあると私は感じている。

16750658.review:
Thanks, valve germany for getting this unbanned, now could you do the same for the other Quake games?

Quake is id software's other 90's FPS giant that co-created the online FPS with all its beloved tropes. Besides the dead as fuck but amazing multiplayer it was known for, Quake's singleplayer consists of four episodes of standard 90's FPS faire about shooting monsters, grabbing keys, finding secrets and getting to the exits, with a le lovecraft xD inspired style and Nine Inch Nails music. What sets Quake apart from Doom and other 90's FPSes is its level of player movement (bunnyhopping, strafejumping, rocket jumping), and set of hitscan and projectile based weaponry that all served a legit purpose in multiplayer in terms of strategies in deathmatching, and as Doom or Duke, Quake ran on MS-DOS, so a source port is most likely necessary for a more convenient (or let alone executable) experience, my recommendations are darkplaces and Quakespasm. While the single player is a nice set of well built and designed levels and enemies, it's a real shame arena shooters died off after the 2000s. Fuck you, 2007.

TL;DR - 4 episodes of beating niggurs and finding good shit

16691724.review:
Quake is a first person shooter that has you traveling through four different dimensions in search of runes that will allow you to fight the main villain. That is pretty much all the story you get and it is up to you to reach the end of each level until you retrieve a ruin and must go to the next dimension. You are free to choose whichever dimension to go to first but I suggest starting from left to right since that introduces all the weapons and enemies much more smoothly. Starting off you must walk into a portal to choose which difficulty you want and to select hard you have to jump over lava which was a nice touch. Your starting weapon is a shotgun, which sounds a lot more awesome than you may think since it is pretty much as useless as the pistol from Doom, disappointingly enough. 

This is a very fast paced shooter where your moving speed is swifter than that of most games sprinting speed these days, which really comes in handy when there is an enemy pouncing toward you and another is shooting grenades at you. Learning an enemy and it's weaknesses is vital to surviving as you will be under attack by several different types of enemies at once and must learn to choose which one poses the biggest threat or simply how to spot an opening. Like in Doom they will also attack each other if they accidentally hit one another, and that can be very advantageous if you have enough skill to cause the enemies to fight each other to the death, as it saves you both ammo and the risk of taking them on yourself.  It is still exhilarating gameplay after all this time and is just as fun today as it was back then.

Environments are still rather acceptable and the atmosphere retains a strong horror vibe to it. Character models have not aged well at all and are rather laughable unfortunately. You will not have time to gawk at them though unless you want a chainsaw to the face. Enemies are pretty versatile since most have both a ranged and close quarters attack. An example is an enemy with a chainsaw attacked to it's arm that will use it when you get too close and a grenade launcher when you are at a distance. That is just one enemy, they usually through multiple types of monsters at you and adapting on the fly is the biggest part of winning a battle. All the enemies are instantly vastly different from one another and instantly recognizable which is a important thing in these type of games. Even a slime is more than capable of killing you if you are not careful.

That same level of awareness is necessary when traversing the levels. You are in their world and if something looks to good to be true it most likely is. One thing that I found strange at first is that there is no activate button and you most shoot or simply walk into to switches to activate them. I was unsure how to feel about this at first, but risking a bit of ammo to shoot something that looks out of place and suspicious to find hidden secrets did end up being much better than pressing your face against walls and mashing the activate key like in Doom. Level design is amazing in Quake and each level somehow manages to feel different than the last. The four dimensions do end up blending together in my mind though since they don't really have any real noticeable gimmicks to differentiate them from one another. There is an extra dimension to fight the bad guy but it is a tiny level and ended up being a very disappointing fight.

As mentioned before your basic weapon to fend off monsters is a underwhelming shotgun and a fire axe in case you are desperate. There is also a double barreled shotgun you come across later on but it is probably one of the most disappointing shotguns I have used in recent memory. It takes about 5-6 point blank shots to take out some of the most common enemies which makes the game feel bullet spongy  but worse still it burns through ammo which you can only carry 100 of that type. A huge disappointment after the legendary double barreled shotgun from Doom 2. Other weapons fair much better and are a lot more useful. There are two versions of guns that shoot nails and are very useful against enemies though ammo does go by quickly. Your most useful weapon will be a grenade launcher which outputs a huge amount of damage and ammo is plentiful though you will obviously not want to use it when enemies are close by.

As is typical from games of this era, there are health kits to replenish your health and armor pickups that will allow you to take more damage. There are other pickups like a hazmat suit that lets you walk on hazards, a quad damage pickup that allows you to completely dominate your foes , a protection pick up that makes you invulnerable for awhile and a golden ring that turns you invisible. Turning invisible sounds cool in theory but once you fire at an enemy they can see you perfectly and avoiding them may not be the wisest choice as you may be attacked by those same enemies if they hear a battle nearby. On the topic of sound one thing that must be mentioned is that the Steam version had all the music removed. I don't know why but if you do not want to mod it back in I wouldn't even bother playing this game.

Quake is still a very playable game if you can get past the dated graphics. It is unlike any other shooter released today and is an extinct brand of FPS which is a real shame. If you are buying it expecting multiplayer do know the community is dead and there are no bots so it all falls to the single player. One heck of a campaign though and it should last you about 6 hours. There is no real reason to play it again other than for fun or wanting to try the hidden difficulty mode. It is a perfect game to pick up and play when you are bored since most levels are only 10 to 15 minutes long. If you are on the look out for some fast paced FPS action or simply want to see why the Quake series is held in such high regards by most, Quake 1 is highly recommended.

16656095.review:
"Classic" is an overused term in gaming.  Because to be classic, a game must catalyse a revolution in style at it's time of release. To be classic, a game must transcend the simplistic outcome of entertainment and  become a canonical representation of both the gaming industry and the zeitgeist. It must raise the bar inalterably. Even by this dizzying standard, QUAKE stands aloft as perhaps the game most deserving the title of "classic game" in the history of the medium.

Continuing id Software's epochal hewing of the FPS out of the shapeless mass of code in the 1990s, QUAKE springboarded off of it's cousin DOOM and formulated the rules of the Shooter that remain strictly enforced today. With being the first of it's kind, QUAKE is a game of absolute purity and speed. Slick as a razors edge and twice as sharp: you can almost feel it's surgical incision as you traverse it's beautifully functional level design, weild it's mathematical precise weaponry and do battle with it's unprecdented opponents.

Reading this, QUAKE may come across as more of an algorithm than a game. But it's biggest feature, as well as it's best one, is it's heart. It is clear that the game is a labor of passion created by geniuses. QUAKE's aesthetic finds itself in the deepest recess of a Lovecraftian nightmare, playing host to ornate keeps haunted by demonic servants of a dark god. When pitted against overwhelming and brutal hordes of monsters clearly on their home turf, QUAKE is a game that will surely send a twang of fear up the spine and a shot of adrenaline into the heart of all gamers, regardless of their tenure.

So, as a gamer, you owe it to yourself to experience this paradigm changing piece of art. If you fancy yourself a Warrior-God of Shooters who feels that you can best any challenge that the industry has thrown at you in the proceeding 20 years, play it on hard. If you're a maniac, play it on Nightmare. Or if you just want to know what all the fuss is about, simply play it. Live it. Let it absorb you like a dark, swirling apocalyptic sky.

All hail the legend that is QUAKE.

16627946.review:
I have to admit, this game's starting to grow on me.

That doesn't mean I'm ignoring it's flaws though.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
First of all, because of the game's poor optimization for modern PCs, you have to set the resolution EVERY.  TIME.  YOU START THE GAME.  And the max resolution is only 1280 x 720.  Also, to enable the ability to look vertically and diagonally, you have to press ` to enter the game console and type in "+Mlook" and to get the crosshair back, you'll have to type in "Crosshair 1".  Again, you have to do this EVERY.  TIME.  YOU ENTER THE GAME.

This port also does not come with the game's soundtrack which many people are pissed off about, BUT honestly I think this is a good thing.  The atmosphere is impressive and honestly the lack of soundtrack really brings that out.  And while the soundtrack is amazing, I still say that the game is better off without it.  It just doesn't really fit in for me.

Also, there's something I have against the enemies and weapons.  Whilst there is a lot of them and they are rather entertaining, the game seems to have a strong habit of constantly throwing fat shreks with chainsaws and grenade launchers in literally every corridor, and it gets really samey and repetetive at times. 

With the weapons, I can't help but feel like some of them are completely worthless.  For instance, you start out with the shotgun on level 1, and you progress onto level 2 and all of a sudden you have the Double-Barrel shotgun, which is basically Quake's faster version of DOOM 2's Super Shotgun which immediately renders the normal shotgun completely worthless.  
Some would argue that DOOM 2 did the exact same thing yet I disagree; the normal shotgun in DOOM 2 had much more range compared to the Super Shotgun and still did a decent amount of damage, but the shotgun in Quake becomes completely forgettable with it's apaulling amount of damage against most enemies in the game.  
Hell, the exact same thing happens for The Nailgun and the Grenade Launcher!  They all get replaced by more powerful copies of their own self, a la the Super Nailgun and the Rocket Launcher.  

This was just my thoughts on it though, you guys probably completely disagree with me.  I just feel as though they could have made some of the weapons in the game actually worth something and not have to be thrown away as completely useless later on.

And what the fuck is the story?  Am I just some dude in some weird places killing random living creatures native to the area because he's a psychopath who enjoys blood, gore and murder?  Until you lot give me the full story, that's what I'm going with.

Also, the graphics occasionally give me headaches.  Just sayin'.

[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
Right, I like the gunplay, it feels really great.  Actually, the combat in general is really satisfying (minus the melee weapon, the axe) through and through.  

The enemy design is really creative, especially for the zombies and each map, despite all having the same atmosphere, all feels unique and different.

Like I said, the atmosphere is brilliant.

Also, that fucking Shambler.  The fucking shambler.  Scary af.

So overall, despite having fuck loads of flaws as of today, Quake still remains to be a fun game and of moderate challenge.

[h1]6/10[/h1]

Still though,

16561901.review:
Quake is a single-player and multiplayer FPS developed by id software and released 1996. It got quite infamous and is recognised today as classic. It was one of the first FPS to fully use polygons to create game enviroment and established multiplayer over Internet on PC.

So, how Steam was handled? It's pretty straight copy-paste. Copy-paste of game folder. Not of game's CD. And that means that music is not just not working, but it's not even included to begin with! You will have to find somewhere soundtrack or music files or CD to get it back. And if mounting CD will not work for you, then I would recommend getting music files and _inmm software to fix it. And even then it looped too early. Soundtrack is quite important in this game, even though I have a bad feeling that most remember this Quake without it.

Now, when you launch the game you will be given the choice between running Quake or Quakeworld. You also will have to choose between Software and OpenGL versions of each.
Quake, also known as WinQuake, is actually a Windows-compilated version of Quake. There wasn't much difference. It's for both Single-player and multiplayer.
QuakeWorld is stricly competive multiplayer. This client was released some time after Quake and was intented to make it more playable on low-speed Internet modems back then. Different way of handling server-client relations.
Software is original Quake rendering. Pixelated, gritty and dark. Lo-fi. I recommend playing game in this mode on low resolution, like in DOS release, it captures Quake feel better than most other fans Source Port. Or OpenGl.
OpenGL mode was added some time after game's release and made use of new-by-then hardware 3D accelration. And well, it's not pretty. First, it lacks some features when it comes to lighting. There is no such thing is "brighter than grey" and there are no special textures that are always full-bright. And then the main point of this mode if to make game look more high-resolution. By making every texture look muddy and uglier, actually. I mean, you can like such thing only if you really hate pixels.

And last thing, once you start playing, write "+mlook" command in console, that you can open with "`" keyboard key. This will enable mouselook. Why it's not part of game's options I don't know, especially seeing how demos make use of mouse in such way.

Plot of single-player is once again simple: There is unknown enemy that was given codename "Quake", who teleports it's army through slipgate. And now that your base was overrun, you have to make use of slipgate to travel to other otherwordly dimension, find out who "Quake" actually is through intermission text and then kick it's butt in most gimmicky way. And then watch the oh so epic bright ending in form text where you are told "id software salutes you".
That pretty much means that you got 4 episodes to choose from beggining, you lose equpment in beggining of each one, the first level of each episode is base themed and actually has unique enemies and then you are off to medieval-like setting.

And yes, when it comes to single-player, one of the best things Quake got to offer was atmosphere. Gritty. Dark. Well, ugly brown at times. you fight some kind of monsters in their low polygonal details. You get weapons like nailgun. It just has a bit of lovecraftian inspiration to it. There are even traps placed here and there. Bloody bloody traps. Soundtrack, while small, contributes a lot to it. And then there are some maps in Episode 4 which play strong on lights blinking or shadows being pitch dark, all in small rooms. Quake is at it's best in such levels. I am pretty sure that people who thought that Doom was scary back then were blown by Quake.

And when you look at more gameplay side of it, well, on theory it should be like Doom but worse. It's slower. Physics are slightly worse, you stop completely upon encountering walls. There is less variety in weapons, even though they introduces grenade launcher, yet some weapons are just direct upgrades to others. Like, Super Shotgun isn't even good at close range, not as much as Super Nailgun. Just something when you run out of ammo on other weapons. There aren't as many enemies, nor as much of variety. You can say that half of Quake gameplay is shooting two rockets at the Ogre, who has grenade launcher and chainsaw. Or shooting 4 times with Super Shotgun at them. And it's too grey at times.

But somehow game pulls through and becomes quite fun. Even if there are less enemies on the levels, it got quite a nice combat to it. And for a game that is supposed to be rushed, level design is great. It got verticality, it is mazey but not too complex, it just has floors on top of each other, fully embracing the fact that game is fully 3D now.
You would think that first introduction to fully polygonal world would be quite underwhelming. That it will underuse it and later games will make it better. But no, Quake still has some good layouts, better than many later games. Should thank that talents at id software were still thinking in abstarct ways, didn't try to be as realistical as Build engine games like Duke Nukem 3D.

It still got some weak points though. Like, Vores, spiders-like demons who shoot homing missiles. Actually, their missiles track players so good, that one corner is not enough to stop them and you can't circlestrafe around them. I don't understand what is the point, what kind of tactic developers wanted to use there. That, and game underdelivers on boss departament. There are only two "proper" bosses in the whole game. And when I say "proper", I actually just mean gimmicky ones.

As for Deathmatch and duel parts, the multiplayer side, well, it's not so good. It made multiplayer over Internet more mainstream and common, yes. But the game balance, it doesn't age too well. It's only good on high-level of play, but same can be said about many games. Yes, it's not Quake-exclusive quality, don't tell me.
You mostly have to dominate arena by grabbing most powerful weapons and powerups. Red Armor is better than any other armor, as it not only gives more armor points, but actually is more effective too. Rocket Launcher shoot quite fast missiles which are too quick to avoid properly. It's also most powerful weapon and most used one. Aside from lighting gun, which is good alternative too. Things die fast there.
So, you just have to grab superior weapons and powerups and then go roflstomp everything else, including those who just spawned in.

It gets even better once you realize that players are actively exploiting glitches in physic engine, like bunnyhopping and voodoo-like strafejumping, thigns that don't make a single sense. It become a standard nowadays, thus creating an artificial barrier between high-level and low-level players, where you have to practice much more than you should have to be as good and have some fighting chances.
So yea, casuals should avoid. Normal players should avoid.

You will have ot use server finders on Internet. And then chances are, there will be barely anybody playing. But then, most still play Quake for duels, so it must not be big issue.

Still better than Valve's Deathmatch Classic.

So yea, game's quality itself is good, but not groundbreaking. Just good game. But what made Quake so overpraised is technical side. The engine. First, it introduced console. Then it allows you to record demos, thus creating competiveness where players try their best and creating some kind of "public". Then when you combine it with glitchy physics, you will see how Speedrunning was created. And then multiplayer was more focused on Internet public. And even better, game allowed more modding abilities, much more than in original Doom. And then it allowed modding in multiplayer. Thus creating Team Fortress mod, for example. And Capture the Flag mode too.

So, yes. Technical amazement, good single-player and finey multiplayer. This is the first Quake.

15754191.review:
Quake is a classic FPS that, alongside Doom, helped Id Software codify the genre. How, I don't know, because Quake is an unbelievably boring game.

The game's plot is, ostensibly, about fighting the Lovecraftian Old God Shub-Niggurath as she does... things. Which are bad. Quasi-demonic invasion from beyond the veil of space. As a Lovecraft fan this would seem rather encouraging... if in practice the game had any real plot at all. In practice the game is almost gleefully self-aware in how much its plot is a thin excuse to commit mass murder.

Quake's "story" is broken up into four Episodes, of which I have admittedly only played the first two. The difference between the two seems to mostly be the upgrade of a single enemy type, and a slightly different wall texture. Any actual plot developments are mostly limited to easily-missed text blurbs at the end of each Episode, which mostly just seem to foreshadow the final boss.

Gameplay-wise, Quake is a tedious, linear run-and-gun set in an endless parade of largely identical brown hallways against the same five brown enemies (with a few exceptions, like the odd miniboss and the very rare "Base" levels featuring soldiers and dogs, all similarly brown), in levels that offer no trace of setting, motivation, or purpose besides a playground to kill things on. The entire game could be proceedurally generated and you'd never notice.

The combat itself is rather annoying. You're equipped with three main ammo types throughout the game - shotgun shells, nails, and rockets - and have two weapons for each, the second being a straight upgrade of the first (except for the grenade launcher and rocket launcher, which have different firing methods with different situational uses). In theory this weapon selection is servicable, but in practice it's rather lacking. Shotguns are the mainstay weapons of the game, probably to minimize the need to actually aim. Nailguns are vastly more effective weapons, basically being automatic weapons that have a degree of aim-assist to them, however their ammo is considerably more sparse and is burnt through much more quickly.

None of this is really a dealbreaker, the truly annoying part is that this game is old enough to have multiple floors overlapping one another, but functionally lack the ability to look up or down. Star Wars: Dark Forces had a similar conundrum mostly solved by the fact that most weapons would aim up or down for you in a limited cone, and your enemies had similar limitations. However, in Quake the most common enemy by far is the Ogre, a stocky brute with a middling level of health and equipped with a chainsaw and a grenade launcher. Bullets shoot straight, but grenades arc with gravity and bounce around corners. Cue every single level filled to the gills with Ogres on high ledges where as often as not you can't hit them, but they will gleefully pelt an endless stream of grenades down on your head.

Don't make the mistake of me blaming my dislike of this game on it's difficulty. I died plenty, but I'm describing the game's combat as "annoying," not "difficult." Quake's uncomplicated setup makes it difficult for anything to become legitimately unbalanced, but managable does not mean fun. And when you take combat that isn't particularly fun, a plot that barely exists, and repetitive, bland aesthetics, you get a game that has essentially no merits to recommend.

15268290.review:
The game is an excellent specimen from the origins of the fps genre; abstract level design, high-octane action, ammo and HP management, key-based progression, and switches and traps everywhere.

THAT SAID, Quake 1 in particular relies very heavily on its excellent atmospheric soundtrack, which (due to technical limitations) isn't included in the steam version. Luckily, there are workarounds, so I still recommend this purchase if you have reason to believe you'll like it.

Workaround A: You can get the free "Dark Places" source port (a sort of "engine upgrade" if you will) online, find the game soundtrack online (in .ogg format) and put it in steamapps\common\quake\Id1\sound\cdtracks. It'll need to be named "Track002.ogg" to "Track011.ogg".

Workaround B: Acquire (e.g. burn) a real physical CD of the game and put it in your drive while you play.

I obviously recommend workaround A.

15204041.review:
Was ein wunderbarer Shooter. Ich erinnere mich an die Tage, als dieses Spiel raus kam und mein Rechner den Anforderungen nicht gewachsen war. Quake war einer der ersten Shooter, der auch echte 3D Gegner auswies. Schön war/ ist auch das völlige Fehlen von Tutorials oder derartigen Dingen -eine Erfindung bei heutigen Shootern, die echt nervt... Damals war alles schön rudimentär: Spiel starten und einfach alles platt machen, was sich bewegt. Lange war das Spiel auf dem Index, ja selbst die bloße Nennung des Spieles barg schon den Verdacht, dass man eine Straftat begann. Aber das ist ein anderes Thema ;-)

Doch nun etwas zu dem Spiel auf Steam:
Man bekommt 4 Modi. Das original Quake in pixeliger Optik, so wie es 1996 verkauft worden ist und Quake World, was ein Online-Mehrspieler Modus darstellt. Beide Varianten gibt es dann noch mal in einer OpenGL-Version.

Die Grafik ist entsprechend Old-School - auch das Options-Menü für die Graifkeinstellung gibt nicht wirklich viel her.

Die Spielweise ist recht einfach und man muss hierzu nichts mehr sagen. Wichtig ist jedoch, dass man mit der Mouse nicht nach oben oder unten schauen kann. Das war damals auch nicht möglich*

Es fehlt auch der Soundtrack, der damals von Nine-Inch-Nails gestellt worden ist - passte wirklich sehr gut zu dem Spiel.

Meine Empfehlung:
Wenn ihr das Spiel kauft, dann zieht Euch unbedingt "DarkPlaces" aus dem Netz. kopiert die Dateien einfach in das Spieleverzeichnis und startet dann die darkplaces.exe. Das Spiel ist dann in Full-HD spielbar und ihr habt eine normale Tastatur-Mouse Steuerung. Auch für den fehlenden Soundtrack gibt es Lösungen im Netz - einfach mal danach googlen. 

Für mich ist Quake 1 einer der besten Shooter, die die Spieleindustrie herausgebracht hat. Klare, Kaufempfehlung von mir.

Edit:
*Nach GeruMeditations Einwand muss ich das hier revidieren - es geht wenn ihr in der Console +mlook angebt. Dann funktioniert die Mouse-Steuerung auch in der reinen Steam Version.

Good times to the nth degree. So many hours playing this game, and even now I still fall back to it occasionally.
This game(+engine) has spawned so many other enjoyable games, yet still holds a special place in my heart.
Back before games spoon-fed you the action or led you around on rails,  Quake kept you jumping(manual, rocket or grenade:D), made you think occasionally, made you work to find 100% of the map Secrets, and then, when the as-written game was done, allowed all sorts of shenanigans undreamt-of in modern games.

15102032.review: That's the kind of game that I shall remember until the end of my life. It was the first 3D FPS that I've ever played and how amazed I was for being able to contemplate enemies that had depth instead of simply being made of some thin texture that would always stare at me (even when dead). The campaign mode is awesome, not only because of the gameplay, music, weapons etc, but also because you have the opportunity of playing it cooperatively with your friends. Talking of multiplayer, although Quake was so innovative back then, it also had to bear the weight of handling dial-up connections from most of the players (except in LANs), making the overall multiplayer conditions somewhat unfair. That's simply because some players had a better connection than others. I've played countless hours of CTF and later Team Fortress (how I miss those crafty grenades and maps). Besides that, I can't remember how many demo videos I've seen in-game, another wonderful resource that created a legacy. Oh well, if I may summarize this game in a single word, it can be only this: Epic.

ポリゴンにて表現された3Dフィールドを舞台にした名作FPS。
『DOOM』シリーズと似た世界観で、ステージクリアタイプのホラーFPSとなっている。
フィールドはほぼ全てポリゴンなので、高さ、奥行きなど現代のFPSの基本は完成している。

シングルモードのみプレイ済だが適度に厳しめな難易度で楽しめた。
弾薬と体力が常に際どい状態で、途中の補給で何とか進めるレベルだった。
敵にしても全体的に高火力で動きが素早く、ジャンプを駆使するパズル的要素もあるため、
難易度的には『DOOM』シリーズより高いと感じた。

steam版だとBGMが流れないため、少々味気ない。
（外部パッチを当てると導入可能とのこと）

ゲーム的には洗練されており、FPSとしても快適に進めた。
高さの概念はあるが、中盤のスイッチを撃つ場面まで操作に気付かなったため注意。
（マウスホイールを押すと、照準の角度を変えられる）

この手のFPSにありがちだが、ラスボスは一風変わった攻略が必要で、苦戦させられた。
ほぼ偶然のクリアとなったが、よくよく見ると「なるほどー」とわかる仕掛けだった。
『Wolfenstein 3D』、『DOOM』後に『Quake』をプレイすると、進化の軌跡がわかって感動できる。


＜一言攻略メモ＞

・マルチプレイは未プレイ。
・敵が強いので、慎重に撃破。特にグレネードを飛ばす敵は厄介。
・照準の角度調整可能なので、索敵＆高い位置の敵を倒しながら進むと良い。
　（デフォルトだとマウスホイール押し込み）
・困ったときはネイルガン連射が強い。
・ラスボス戦は、落ち着いて周囲観察。怪しいと思ったら色々探ってみるべし。

14665525.review:
And... lightning does in fact strike the same place twice.

If you like, you could just read my DOOM review, swapping the word QUAKE for DOOM. But that wouldn't be fair.

iD managed to produce another industry changer, a scant three years after DOOM was released. Whereas DOOM brought 3D gaming to the masses and made multiplayer something that people felt should be included as standard, QUAKE raised the bar even higher.

PC Gamer certainly helped QUAKE along, thanks to including the shareware episode on their coverdisc. So those people not lucky enough to have fast internet access could still join in the fun.

I think at the time, QUAKE was even more of a global sensation than DOOM was, but with hindsight I think it's fair to say that DOOM shook things up more than QUAKE did. But only just. A lot of QUAKE's legacy is thanks to the addons and patches which quickly followed the main game.

QUAKE proved that smooth, fluid, entirely polygon-based games were feasible and practical. Suddenly, all the sprite-based FPS games that were being released looked incredibly dated. Not their fault - nobody but iD saw it coming. Duke Nukem 3D had been released just one month before iD pushed their tech demo out into the world, and everybody knew something big was coming.

If DOOM made multiplayer gaming on company LANs the next big thing, then QUAKE made internet deathmatches the in-thing. Quakeworld which followed later on in the year greatly improved and streamlined this service so even those with dial-up connections could participate.

GLQuake greatly improved the graphics for those lucky few who had these new-fangled 3D accelerator cards - suddenly everybody was buying Matrox and Voodoo cards just to play the new, improved QUAKE.

And if people thought DOOM was expandable, QUAKE blew their minds. Not only could you make levels, you could make new models, new sound and music, and even rewrite parts of the code to make entirely new games (QUAKE Chess anybody?)

Personally, QUAKE is not my favourite FPS. Not by a long shot. I don't think I ever even finished the single-player campaign. But I can't deny it's influence, and it is amazing to see what they did with the hardware at the time.

14653841.review:
Review at A Glance

Pros:
Grand-daddy of full 3D First Person Shooters
Gripping, visceral, atmospheric soundtrack
Inventive, diverse level and enemy design (Lovecraftian)
Addictive multiplayer gameplay, with myriad iterations/mods; alive to this day
Unparalleled, dark, medieval, ghoulish atmosphere

Cons:
So many Source Ports and MODS, which ones to choose?!!?
****Steam version does not include the game's original Soundtrack, easy online fix available****

Conclusion:
Essential gaming for fans of First Person Shooters; cemented the id Software legend. Most popular game engine of its time. If you don't have this already, what are you waiting for?! For current generation play, I recommend one of the common source ports, such as Ultimate Quake (DarkPlaces+).

In-depth review, not for the faint of heart: "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here":

1996. DooM had introduced "Deathmatch" to the popular lexicon three years earlier. id Software managed to capitalize on the addictive nature of online multiplay, while advancing the technical limits of FPS gaming. What followed was the most popular game engine of its time, and it revolutionized online multiplay. Engine novelties included polygonal models, fully 3D environments, easy tools for Game Modding and hardware 3D acceleration. Quake may single handedly be the game that made a cutting-edge graphics card an essential component for the modern PC gamer. Unique gameplay features included bunny hopping and rocket-jumping. Game emphasis was on the online, multiplayer experience, utilizing a client-server model rather than peer to peer, the preeminent model of the time. This model allowed players to create and mantain a session, while additional players would be able to join or leave at any time, without disrupting the game. 

Story: 

BAHAHAHAHAHAH!! Story?! Pffffftt. Don't let it get in the way of an epic, legendary, awesome FPS game. Beat the 4 episodes and collect the rune at the end, solve environmental puzzles, kill everything with a pulse...or rather, that moves! 'Nuff Said. There is something resembling a story that was thrown in to provide the semblance of a gaming thread.

Gameplay:

Fast paced, bunny hopping, rocket jumpin' non-stop, edge of your seat, deathmatchin' action. Gameplay intuitive enough to allow a beginner to jump in and start fraggin', yet, complex enough to allow a bustlin' pro scene to develop, and spawn a successful franchise. Responsive controls allow you to float through inspired levels and maneuver your character, even when airborne! Weapon selection established the standard with a good variety of now conventional, classic weapons; including the revered Shotgun, the seminal Rocket Launcher and the mighty Lighting Gun. Weapon balance and choice, depending on level design and range of combat, had never been this intricate.

Design: 

Iconic palette hard on black/browns with excellent use of lighting and shadows for emphasis and scares. Weapon design is a bit blocky, by today's standards, but sits nicely with the dark, medieval theme. Enemy/monster designs are inventive, with great variety, and a multitude of baddies that attack from above, at ground level and in the water. At the time, probably the only other big title that offered hazards with such a degree of freedom of movement was "Descent."  Enemies appear as something out of a medieval demonic nightmare with a hodgepodge of humanoid, hellish Lovecraftian creatures coming at you and wielding a good array of weapons and attacks. The color palette and enemy design allows for baddies to pop out of dark corners and portions of the level, setting up multiple scares, providing a racemic mixture of action and horror that is hard to match.

The level design, with its gothic architecture and variety of environmental puzzles and hazards, resulted in classic levels that would eventually be ported to multiple other engines and games. 

Sound: 

Immaculate, crisp environmental, creature, character and weapon sound effects that were mostly concocted/mixed in-house by the talented id crew utilizing innovative techniques and processing. Trent Reznor/NIN soundtrack provides a chilling backdrop with industrial, ambiental brilliance that peppers the game with a pumping, blood curling soundtrack, which seamlessly potentiates the dark visuals and sound effects.

Replayability: 

The online multiplayer experience is at the core of Quake. It would offer more options than any other FPS at the time and, out of the box, would allow for Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch and Cooperative Play. It would also allow for Time and/or Frag limits. After some time, popular free modifications included Team Fortress and Capture the Flag modes. The transition to a Client:Server model would permit a server to run continuously and for players to drop in and pop out of the game, without interrupting it. This dramatically improved the chances of finding a working game. Moreover, whereas most multiplayer experiences at the time emphasized 1:1 or games of up to 8 players, Quake allowed up to 16 simultaneous players in its original iteration; resulting in unprecedented chaos and murderous destruction.


Conclusion: 

Quake is a legendary, classic game from FPS greats, id Software (id Tech 2). The Quake engine fueled the upcoming games for a generation and set the blueprint for FPS and online gaming. Dark atmosphere with ghoulish, sadistic enemy design set in a medieval, gothic world full of environmental dangers and light puzzles. Online experience is the core of the game, and would shape the FPS landscape for the foreseeable future. If you enjoy FPS, horror, inventive level design, Lovecraftian creatures, NIN/Trent Reznor or are just interested in gaming history, you cannot go wrong with this game.

14378108.review:
Is this the last "classical" FPS?  Or the first "modern" shooter?  After nearly two decades I'm not even sure anymore.  All brown jokes aside, consider the following:

* Graphics and lighting that have aged beautifully, unless you're an unrepentant graphics whore.
* Incredibly immersive sound design and score by Trent Reznor that beats most games today (playing SP campaign in the dark with headphones can get ridiculously unnerving)
* FAST, FLUID, SKILLFUL GAMEPLAY -- YOU CAN AND WILL DIE.  BRUTALLY.

And I'm not even going to talk about the mods, or multiplayer, or any of that other stuff we take for granted thanks to the breakthroughs this game made.  We all know.  

It's not much more than a slight update of the DOOM formula, without ever really hitting those same heights, but I keep coming back to this game once in a while simply because - well, because they don't make them like this anymore.  There's the most grudging attempt at a story, not nearly as many enemies as you'd like, and a confusing mish-mash of design elements owing to the chaos at iD.  But it's a classic anyway, and IMO the last great iD title, because it just wants to be fun and atmospheric.  And it succeeds.

Boot it up.  Blow off some steam.  Gib some grunts.  Axe a dog.

13776919.review:
This is one of the best games ever made, and certainly my favourite despite the huge number of other mind-numbingly awesome games I have played. Whilst the original game might not stand up in some ways to modern FPS games, its focus on simple satisfying carnage, and near total lack of a story or any semblance of realism to get in ther way of said carnage makes it one of the most pure and enjoyable FPS games in existence.

The main game is fairly short, but there are so many add-on levels and mods, you could easily be playing this for hundreds of hours without running out of new content. It also supports coop play, so you can blast through the main game and various mods together, and when you get sick of coop, you play one of the first ever deathmatch FPS games. Although Doom had deathmatch, it was Quake that caused an explosion in its popularity, and through mods spawned many new deathmatch modes, such as CTF and even Team Fortress.

Although there have been games since that have tried to bring players the classic gameplay focussed carnage of Quake and Doom, few have come anywhere near to the greatness of the originals. You'd be mad not to try this game if you've never played it before.

Disclaimer: I played Quake from 1996 when it came out. I still play now from time to time. I don't play the Steam version, hence I don't have much recorded playtime (just played ep1 to get enough to write this review! Still fun as hell).

Also, although the Steam version of the game works fine, I recommend getting hold of modern engine, such as Quakespasm to play it with. Check out the website Quaddicted to get new levels, mods and engines.

Quake is undeniable. If you're on this store page, you shouldn't need me to tell you how great Quake is, but I am here to assure you that, with a few little patches, you can still play the Quake of your memories.

The Steam version, like most digital copies, doesn't include the soundtrack, and GabeN obviously doesn't much care for physical media, so there's not much chance of him sending you a CD. Don't dismay, though. There are all kinds of guides to get the soundtrack up and running, and what a difference it makes! The memories of countless hours spent fragging came flooding back. A few graphical tweaks, and the game actually looks as good as I thought it did the first time I saw it played.

If you ever enjoyed Quake, or if you're some kind of child or mutant who's never played before, you owe it to yourself to drop the paltry sum, and experience this masterpiece of foundational game design (foundational to its genre, at any rate) again, or for the first time.

13614819.review:
Quake es EL videojuego. 
Para mi el más importante de la historia. Primero en estar desarrollado completamente en 3D y en utilizar muchas de las técnicas que hoy en día rigen cualquier juego que tenemos en nuestra biblioteca. Fruto del mejor programador que ha parido el sector nunca John Carmack y con un diseño de niveles increíble aún a día de hoy (mi agradecimiento eterno a John Romero y American McGee por esta maravilla). Es el juego que cambió el sector para siempre.

Poder volver a jugarlo más de 18 años después ha sido fantástico, ver que sigue proporcionando esa adrenalina que solo los juegos de ID han sabido dar. Esta versión de Steam se puede disfrutar completamente en un PC actual, solamente recordad de activar mediante la consola el comando "+MLOOK" para poder tener la vista con el ratón.

13601177.review:
What's there to say about Quake? One of the most world-renowned and memorable FPS' of all time. But why is that the case? Let's take a detailed look and see:

1. Gameplay - Let's trim the fat and get right to the guts right off the bat; Quake's gameplay is that of your typical 90's old-school FPS: Fast, bloody, complex and hard as hell, and you will love it (if you're into FPS games, that is). You get a wide array of weapons from a harmless Axe to the dreaded Thunderbolt, which turns any enemy into mincemeat in seconds, including the dreaded Shambler. Also like any old-school FPS, it is rife with secret areas that are a chore to find, but well worth the rewards within! Most times, at least. Tons of pick ups like the Pentagram of Protection (Invulnerability), Ring of Shadows (Invisibility), and the all-too-memorable Quad Damage, allowing you to unleash doomsday to every enemy in sight -- and yourself, too, if you aren't careful! -- dealing a massive 400% damage with any weapon you choose! There is a wide variety of enemies you will also encounter, from the annoying Grunt to the creepy Vore. Hint: When you see a Fiend (the bipedal, ape-like thing with lacerator arms) run like hell. One leap attack, and you're near dead. No joke.

2. Graphics - Usually graphics aren't one thing to take too seriously in reviews. In my philosophy, so long as you can see where you are going, and nothing looks TOO pixelated, they're perfectly tolerable. Buuuuuuuuut, that being said, download the Ultimate Quake Patch to be able to play this game in buttery-smooth 1920x1080 (if you have a full HD monitor that is). Never before has a game from the 90's looked so crisp and clear. And to think at one point I thought the 320x240 resolution of Quake on the N64 was the best thing ever. *shudders*

3. Difficulty - Hoo, boy...if you are brave enough to play this game on Nightmare (which you should to get the full experience, as cliche as that may sound, I know), this game will keep you on the edge of your seat nearly at all times, especially once you start encountering the bigger, badder enemies in later levels. Also, beware the Spawns (the bouncy slime-things). Just...just trust me on this.

4. Replay value - I could start this beauty up and play it any day of the week and have fun with it. It's fast-paced, bloody FPS action at its finest, and one of the true granddaddies of the FPS genre, along with Doom, Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem 3D.

Bottom Line: You want this game. It's usually like, $3 or something. Absolute steal and a half. As are the expansions! But I'll review those by themselves.

13597491.review:
[h1]Let's Quake begun![/h1]
Именно так. Quake\Q\Квака - практически нон-стоп шутер, с ураганным геймплеем; огромными пушками; толпами разнообразных монстров; великолепным левел-дизайном, что погружает игрока в некое средневековье альтернативной реальности, в которой виной всему - некое создание, под тем самым названием "Quake".
Игровой процесс повествует о единственном безымянном солдате, который был отправлен через телепортационные врата, с целью найти и уничтожить то, что в свою очередь намечает посетить и уничтожить мир и все живое.
Игра состоит из пары десятков уровней, через которые в ураганной мясорубке предстоит "пролететь" каждому, кто запустит сей старенький шедевр, и отдаст должное старой эпохе классического шутера от первого лица.

[h1]id tech revolution[/h1]
Релиз этой игры состоялся в далеком 1996-ом году, спустя всего несколько месяцев, после выхода не менее шедеврального (и по сей день актуального) Duke Nukem 3D! 
Технологически игра студии id Software на голову выше всех предшествующих игор жанра. Эта игра стала прорывом в новую веху 3D-шутеров! Имея в своем сердце полную поддержку трех-мерных моделей окружения, когда в DN3D, и в том же Doom царила псевдо-трёхмерность. То есть трех-мерную иллюзию создавали лишь стены, а в качестве монстров и оружия выступали спрайты. Квака же была полностью передовой: будь то аптечка; оружие, или даже монстр - все это были и есть модели. Спрайты так же присутствовали в игре, они и по сей день во многих играх рисуют иллюзии дыма, или огня... практически всех эффектов. Также, благодаря поддержке шейдеров, движок отрисовывал великолепные эффекты освещения. Парадоксально, но все же игра была выдержана в мрачных, темных тонах.

[h1]Окружение.[/h1]
В Кваке присутствует огромное кол-во аптечек. Ты спросишь, мой юный камрад: -А что это такое\Для чего они? -Все дело в том, что раньше, не было такого понятия "кино в игре". В олдскульных шутанах нет контрольных точек (что так любят консоли). Нет и сильной одышки ГГ, приводящей к регенерации здоровья. Так же, в этой, и многих других играх жанра, можно (ты не поверишь) заблудиться на уровне! Да-да, тебя никто не будет водить за ручку, и кричать что-то типа:-Ну же, давай,скорее, к скриптованной к.т.! Тебя не заставят выжидать в укрытии. В этом нет необходимости... впрочем, ты можешь попробовать это.
Эту, как и многие другие игры можно в прямом смысле этого слова пролететь, и поставить очередной рекорд! Но для этого тебе понадобятся "чертежи" геометрии уровней, и смекалка, которая подскажет, где и как срезать, чтобы пролететь через пол карты к телепорту на следующий уровень.

[h1]Немного ПРО сетевую игру по модему.[/h1]
Этой игре стоит отдать еще одно должное: звание великой прародительницы сетевых баталий. Именно в этой игре (задолго до популярной кс) начали проходить чемпионаты мира, такие как CPL, WCG и DreamHack. Изначальный мультиплеер игры, как оказалось, не был готов к принятию обширной аудитории, и был целенаправлен на игру по локальной сети (практически вырвал из Вики). Но позднее id запилили Quake World, со значительно переделанной механикой, той самой, что Вы можете видеть в нынешней Ку Лайв.

[h1]"Современное прошлое"[/h1]
id Tech стал сердцем многих других игр компании, а так же, на его основе было создано приличное кол-во игр (в том числе, всеми нами любимая вселенная Half-Life).

P.S. Хоть в игре и есть поддержка OpenGL (кто не в курсе, это такая фишка всех версий движка игр id, что позволяет запускать игры на отличительных операционках Windws - Linux'е. Еще эта штука была фишкой стареньких ускорителей семейства Nvidia, которая позволяла запустить игру в более комфортном виде, с какой-то точки зрения). На современном железе игра не будет выглядеть так эпично, как это было "в каменном веке". На эту игру существуют разные порты, с крутыми шейдерами, HD-текстурами и т.д. Все это конечно же облегчит, и придаст комфорту игровому процессу.

И еще одно немало важное сообщение: раньше, все разработчики были щедры к фанатам, и выкладывали в свободный доступ инструменты для ковыряний своих детищ. Но только не Monolith, которые создали великий Blood! В связи с этим и страдает игра от нехватки адекватного, современного порта...

...если ты все же это дочитал, то ты получил свой заслуженный чекпоинт, и достижение любопытного читалкина! Спасибо за внимание! ушел строчить мнение о Квак Два!

13588091.review:
Quake - легендарный шутер, вышедший в далёком 1996 году, первый fps с полноценной трёхмерной графикой. Не было бы кваки - неизвестно, как выглядела бы игровая индустрия на сегоднешний момент. Всякие баттлфилы и колдьюти - не один я вижу в них отсылки к игре 20-летней давности?
Итак, к самой игре претензий нет. Да, сегодня она далеко не всем придётся по душе, но сыграть определённо стоит. Она шедевреальна.   
Теперь к негативному. Немного огорчила steam-версия игры. Как уже писали ранее, в ней отсутсвует саундтрэк (музыка придавала игре небывалую атмосферу). и более того у меня возникли проблемы с настройкой мыши и прочими игровыми конфигурациями. На форумах поговаривают, что стимовская версия у многих частенько крэшится.
Благо существует патч, который всё и вся исправляет.
Короче говоря, нам подсунули далеко не новую версию 0.95, на которой и в мультиплеер уже никто не играет (кстати, для нормальной игры в мульте советуют скачать отдельный клиент - танцы с бубнами обеспечены). Не знаю, зачем издатель так поступил. Возможно, у него были серьёзные на это основания (или же он хотел дать нам наинатуральнейший квейк, чёрт его знает). Короче говоря... отнесём это к минусам. Получается, что претензии занимают большую часть этого скромного обзора, но об очевидных плюсах этой игры было уже много сказано ранее.
Я советую приобрести эту игру, потому что при её прохождении я получил истинное геймерское удовольствие. На фоне выходящих новинок просто было интересно узнать, во что играли представители прошлого поколения.

13567549.review:
[h1] Overview [/h1]
One of the oldest FPS' out there. Even to this day, the pixelated display (Which can be sorted with a retextured version named 'Quake Epsilon'), retro music, run and gun themes and level design still retain at least some of their widespread popularity. Definitely not for hipster gamers, who play their stupid little 2d pixel 'art' games, this is for real gamers who need a little trip down memory lane. 

[h1] System [/h1]
Quake runs as it should, anything that causes too much trouble rarely occurs. The controls aren't too hard to master, plus they aren't buggy (As I've found with some other olden games). The controls aren't dissimilar from most modern-day games, with the exception of specialised buttons like turn left 5 degrees or something. It's just point and shoot. No need to reload.

[h1] Multiplayer [/h1]
The one thing that doesn't really work well in the original Quake is the co-op/multiplayer. It is usually pretty buggy and laggy, and controls have been known to break and/or unbind in a match. Plus, the multiplayer mechanics don't really gel with each other. Sometimes, the AI will just completely break down and enemies will just stare in the direction the editors placed them in and won't attack or move. This also means entities with any properties won't activate or do anything. The single player campaign is good enough on its own, however.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This game is very good, considering the times it was made in. Newer versions have been released (The aforementioned Quake Epsilon) that make it easier to see what's actually happening. For such an old game, Quake still remains impressive and a fun experience. It may be like Destiny story-wise (It has none), but it certainly makes for a fun pick-up-and-play game when you're bored. 8/10.

Alright, we're done here.

13280307.review:
Quake.

If you’re here, the odds that you know what Quake is are pretty significant, so this review might seem a little (or quite a bit) pointless.

But, Quake has a special meaning to me – Quake and I go way back, it being one of the first games I would ever play, along with Half-life and Doom. I still remember those days, zipping around those moody corridors and those dank, decrepit hallways, filling everything that moved with as many rounds as my 6-year-old hands were able to pump out...
 
Before inevitably dying at the hands of some monstrosity, of course.

Sure, I wasn’t good at it by any conceivable degree, but damn, I still loved it. It was more than just a game to me, the environment, the enemy design – it all came together to create an experience that I just can’t seem to dig out of my head, not that I would ever want to. Even now, I still feel that urge to boot it up and shoot something.

I can’t promise that your time with Quake will be anything similar to mine, and you may find it to be dated, uninteresting or dull (and, in my opinion NONE of those things can define Quake). But to me, Quake will always be there, flashing through the back of my mind, making me feel the same way about it as I did 12 years ago, and because of that, I have no choice but to recommend it.

13217191.review:
The Single-player is lacking in the weapon and enemy variety from Doom, but it introduced a atmosphere through visuals and sound that stands alone from other shooters.  

The mutliplayer remains the bedrock of user created content, introducing modes like CTF that are standard in every shooter from then to now.

The engine itself is one of the biggest milestones in gaming histroy, which laid down the ground work for Half-Life and a list of others that'd be better read in a wiki article than here.

This isn't so much of a review as it is just a brief reflection of how intregal Quake is to the history of gaming, there's plenty of Youtube documentaries than go more in-depth if you want to learn more, but the point I'm trying to make, is that if you have a passion for the FPS genre or gaming as a whole then it's worth it to experience Quake for yourself.

12720519.review:
Id Software's Quake is the game that popularised online deathmatches. This first game in the Quake series is inspired by Gothic-style environments, medieval settings and Satanic imagery (similar to id's predecessor, Doom). It also has been the starting point and an influence on user mods, machinimas and speedruns.

Thanks to Trent Reznor, founder/leading singer of Nine Inch Nails, his music and sound design/effects for the game added to the creepiness factor of the game, other members of the band contributed to the soundtrack as well. Though in order to get the soundtrack for the Steam version, you need the Ultimate Quake Patch.

Quake is also the game that the original Team Fortress was based on by John Cook and Robin Walker (who are now working in Valve).

Its singleplayer campaign consists of four episodes of eight levels each (including a secret level). You play a protaganist only known as Ranger sent into a portal to defeat an enemy codenamed Quake. As you collect weapons/items, they are carried over to the next level. The higher level you reach, the more challenging and intense it becomes than the last.

12634200.review:
If you loved DOOM or DOOM II then Quake is a god-send. The Original Quake was THE FIRST TRUE 3D First Person Shooter ever made. And it did (then as well as now, if anyone could see past then next CoD) phenominally. 
32 is the magic number when it comes to great FPS' , as all 32 levels (and 6 underplayed 'Deathmatch' levels) were intense and enjoyable from start to finish.


    The Original Quake may as well have been a DOOM spin-off during it's initial release, but copying a great formula isn't always a bad thing, IF you know where to go with it. Quake knew EXACTLY what it was doing, and IMPROVED upon all of DOOM's previous work. Taking DOOM 2's 32 level formula, the ability to look up and down (It was REVOLUTIONARY I TELL YOU!!!!!!!), intense gore (which, back then made the game "M for Mature" but now, with graphical updates, the gore has been downgraded too "T for Teen"), fast-paced (CoD has NOTHING on this) multiplayer, and over the top violence (A.K.A. The AXE OF EXPLOSIONS, seriously... no joke... go smash up a corpse with this thing...), that made it a 'Must have' for EVERY gamer that owned Windows 95.

     NOTICE (FOR CLARIFICATION ONLY, You can skip this if you want):Now, I must clarify one thing, I didn't grow up on DOOM or DOOM II or even Quake, BUT I believe Wolfenstein, Spear of Destiny, DOOM, DOOM II, Quake, and all of the other great 90's First Person Shooters are what we should all take a page from when making the next CoD. SERIOUSLY my first First Person Shooter was CALL OF DUTY 4 for God's sake! When I played DOOM for the first time I was... how shall I say this....MIND BLOWN, FLOORED, & BLOWN THROUGH THE FRONT DOOR! SERIOUSLY! I play CoD 4 now and I'll ALWAYS go back to DOOM & DOOM II before the day's up.

     The Original Quake is, in my opinion, better than Quake 2 & 4 (Which are basically part of a 'mini-trilogy' I call
 "The Quake Wars"), Quake 1 is entirely seperate from the rest of the series. It is closer to a fully 3D DOOM game more than Quake's 2, 4, and Enemy Territory: Quake Wars (A.K.A The Quake Wars Trilogy)  Quake is the name of the final Boss in this game, though (Can this really be a spoiler? I mean, all I said was the name, right?) not a boss in The Quake Wars Trilogy, has no mention of even the name "Quake" EXCEPT when the Intro of Enemy Territory: QW has a slip-gate (pretty much a space teleporter) shaped like the logo summon invading ships. 

    NOW, all mentions of other games aside.... Quake is an addicting, fast paced, rocket jumping (yes, we has those), barrel O' fun. In the words of a wiseman ~ "In my day, we rocket jumped to school, both ways." - Wise guy, 20XX (because I don't remember his name or the year). You would be a FOOL to pass this game up, give it a try, there's NOTHING to lose, and everything to GAIN!

P.S. It is ALMOST REQUIRED to have this installed onto the game to make run properly on modern PC's:  
http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1756923 
(The ULTIMATE Quake Patch IS LITTERALLY the 'Best Thing Since Rocket Jumps')

Being, as it is, the last game before John Romero's ill-fated departure from the legendary id Software, this is as much a piece of gaming history as it is a game.
don't be fooled by that description, this is one hell of a game, while its graphics and gameplay are dated now, there is still that visceral thrill similar to DOOM that is timeless. sure, newer and arguably better games have been and gone since the mid-1990s, there is still something compelling about Quake, something that hasn't really been captured since Timesplitters: Future Perfect. while the steam version isn't perfect (it's lacking the music from the cd version, something that can be rectified with mods), it is still a visceral thrill to play, and in a first for id software, you start with the shotgun, meaning the awesome starts right at the beginning.
the fast-paced action present in this game that, may i remind you, is nearly 20 years old will keep you coming back for decades to come. it is as timeless as super mario bros.

12273499.review:
Quake is one of the best Id titles around. It has bad ass weapons, enemies, sound effects and music (provided by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails). 

It has very interesting level design that is a lot more advanced than Doom's. Each episode starts out in a military base that has a portal to other dimensions, so there's lots of variety in each episode. 

The enemies range from grunts with shotguns to giants who shoot lightning, there's a lot of things in between.

 Weapons are amazing, with sound effects that make them all seem very powerful. The weapons in Quake are all very useful for various situations, it is important to learn each weapons functionality. 

Armor is a very important item in Quake. You die much quicker in Quake without armor than you do in other games from this time period, so always be well stocked up on armor. 

My only complaints are that only the first episode ends in a boss fight, the rest do not, though the other 3 episodes are much harder than the first, still a boss fight for each rune would've been nice. Another thing, Quake has aged quite a bit, in the 90s Quake was a pretty scary game, but at least for me, its fear factor is no longer present. 

A Steam version only complaint, Steam Quake doesn't loop the music tracks on its own, you must use a patched EXE and rip the CD audio to mp3 format to get it to work (there is a guide on Steam about how to do this). This should not be a problem, but it is, and it seems to be a problem that plagues not only Quake, but other CD audio based games such as Quake II, Hexen II, Blood, and more. There are no achievements, which doesn't bother me but it might bother others. I have yet to try online play with the Steam version so I have no real comment, but Quake multiplayer is amazing, I hope that it works on Steam.

If you like Doom, or other FPS games of the 90s, you'll love Quake.

Totally get this game that revolutionizes the 3D world of gaming.

12099966.review:
I've been playing Quake 3 for a veeery long time, but when I found the Quake Collection, I got all the Quake games (except for Quake 4) and some expansions.

Quake is a fun singleplayer game, similar to the classic Doom game, and has some really fun weapons to kill with. I'm planning to finish this game, then Quake 2 and then the expansions. Multiplayer does exist, but it's made by modders and it doesn't seem to be very popular. It's easy to forget about the storyline since the monster-killing and the fast pace is too distracting, but that doesn't make the game bad.

Quake is picture-perfect, however the saving process can be a pain in the ass. You progress far into a level, then you die and you realize you forgot to save at a previous area, since there is no autosave. And then you have to play the level all over again. That's something you learn once you die, and it can be hard for someone like me to remember to save often. Of course, Quake can be modded, so you could make an autosave possible somehow...
When you start playing the game, you notice you can only look to the left and right like in Doom. It can be fixed if you want by typing '+mlook' into the console ingame, and it will work like any other FPS game.

All in all, I personally think this game is awesome and I'd recommend it to those who want to enjoy some good ol' classic, fast-paced games.

12033302.review: When it comes to first person shooter games, I've almost always preferred the old to the new. Games like Doom, Duke Nukem 3D, Team Fortress Classic, and most importantly, this game. Quake is one of my favorite games of all time, and a top contender for my favorite first person shooter. If you are a gamer that enjoys reloading constantly, passively regenerating health, being guided linearly from point A to point B in the story, and generally playing behind a safety net, then good for you. But Quake is a fast paced, old school, top of the class shooter that refuses to hold your hand. The fast paced gameplay, the need for exploration to find every secret to help you through, the challenging, hard hitting enemies and weapons, and the fact that you can die extremely quickly if you screw up. That is what a good shooter is to me, and I can't think of a better example of where that shines than Quake. If you haven't played this game before, I can't recommend it enough, and if you're a long time fan of the Quake series like me, then you understand why I feel the way I do about this game. 10/10.

11860967.review:
Quake is the legendary old-school first person shooter from ID Software that was a step up from Doom as a true 3D game. The controls are simple, move, strafe, shoot, jump and change weapons. It is fast paced and you can strafe avoid most everything, so if you get hit, its your own fault. Because this is such a fast paced game, gone is the use button, instead you'll walk up to a button or a door and automatically interact with it.

As a shooter, Quake features a lot of guns such as double barreled shotguns, various versions of nail guns (machine guns), grenade and rocket launchers. The weapons feel nice and have great impact, everything from making an enemy fall backward to gib explosions everywhere! There are no throwable grenades or alt fire, but the weapons feel so good to use you won't need them.

You'll need the diverse array of weapons to take on an army of enemies in every level. Everything from standard soldiers and attack dogs to grenade launching chainsaw wielders and electric shocking giant yetis. There is a diverse array of enemies, that always keeps ramping up the challenge and tactics you'll need to kill them. The enemies will fight against one another, which is fun to see, but there aren't factions that you'll see intentionally compete against each other, but Quake still boils down to you vs everything else.

The levels are expertly designed, but can be overly brown, but I guess a game named Quake makes me think inner earth and inner earth makes me think brown. Each level will have you going up, down, forward, opening doors, finding keys, falling in traps, jumping over lava, finding secrets, swimming through ugly water, dodging enemies and murdering much more. It is not straight forward, but you won't get lost, because it is well designed. There are four episodes with 8 or so levels each. Not just that, but because this game is so old and was so wildly popular, it has a million mods and levels.

For new players, there is no regenerating health, but health and ammo are abundant, this is an action game. Kill an enemy, get rewarded with ammo. There is also armor that will let you take more damage.

The music was performed or designed by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails and feels like a touch of ambiance amongst scratch guitars. The nail gun ammo also has NIN logos.

The Steam version of Quake offers QuakeWorld compatibility, but the big problem with that is QuakeWorld uses GameSpy servers, which were shut down. There are no achievements, but it is still a classic game that holds up today as one of the greatest old-school first person shooters.

In all this is a fantastic game that uses a game engine that spawned dozens of other engines.

Trent Reznor.

Amazing, fast paced, run-and-gun FPS gameplay from the mid-90s. An ID software classic with awe inspiring gothic theme. 

Quake is all about an invasion of Earth by Shub-Niggurath (a cthulhu like being which resembles a Dark Young) via a series of slipgates created by humanity in an attempt to create teleportation technology. Without this game there would be no Half Life or Call of Duty. Period.
