11488528.review:
For a game nearly as old as myself, Quake has held up VERY well. Each level is a medieval maze filled with monsters and creatures straight out of your worst nightmares who all want to kill you. Starting with just a shotgun, you collect your weapons as you progress until you have an arsenal good enough to take on anything you could encounter. 

As older games do, Quake doesn't go easy on you. Even on the easy levels, I often found myself in dire need of either health, armor, or ammo. Learning what weapons work best, what traps to avoid, and where to look for secret health packs is vital to your survival in this nightmarish world.

For me, the best part of this game is the movement. Fast movement and the ability to bunnyhop around enemies you just can't fight at the moment really seals the deal on this excellent game.

And let's not forget that a mod of this series led to Team Fortress 2, everyone's favorite game at some point. Also rocket jumping. GOD I love rocket jumping. 

Also install the Ultimate Quake Patch. It adds the original soundtrack and a load of other fixes to make this game even more wonderful.

11291868.review:
With the addition of the new episode released by Machine Games called DOPA (I believe people refer to it as Dimensions of Past? What's the A stand for?) I felt like I needed to rework this review.

This is the tightest, bloodiest, most fluid 3D action game you could ever play. 
From this and Quake II is where the FPS genre all sprouted.

Quake is a dark, medieval, Lovecraftian themed FPS based on what was going to be a Dungeons and Dragons game. You start of in a strange Hub world where you can select difficulty, the Hard difficulty decoured with a broken bridge surrounded by lava, and walls with dead bodies stapled to it, indicating that it's not for your average player.
Next thing you know, you're in a large room with four Slipgates leading to four separate dimensions, all different, but all overrun by bloody horrors.
It's up to you, the player, to clear all four dimensions of these bloody thirsty monsters, and the overlords of each dimension.

Gameplay: 
This game is where terms like 'Rocket Jump' and 'Bhopping' orginated from. This is the grand-daddy of those. The aiming is so incredibly responsive, the guns all feel so satisfying to shoot, even the basic shotgun. The level design is impossible and sensical at the same time, which gives a huge impression that you are just traversing a Cthulu version of M.C. Escher's Crazy Stairs, and it's so good. Enemies can be tricky and all have their own attack mechanics which requires thought. There's PUZZLES for god's sake.

This is a game for "the" FPS entusiast -- there's no reason anyone would not like this game. It's action packed from the first rotweiler running at you from across a bridge to the death of Shub'Niggurath.

If you have any correlation with the aged graphics engine, there's tons of addons and sourceports you can run from, that will still allow you to play within Steam. I play on Darkplaces with the "normal" graphics settings, which gives you close-to-original graphics without all the blurriness.

Overall:
It's Quake, why wouldn't you buy it?

11161471.review:
Quake is a masterpiece, plain and simple.

Quake may be one of my favorite games, but I'll try to make this review as unbiased as possible. Created in 1996, Quake was revolutionary at the time. Following after Doom (Both created by the wonderful ID Software), Quake took all of what Doom did right and pushed it into the third dimension. The levels, music, and enemies all go beyond the call of duty and make this game a timeless classic.

Quake is heavily inspired by the works of H.P. Lovecraft, creating a dark and medieval setting. The dark shades of brown, green and bright reds in later levels really play to this note. This is not just to play homage to Lovecraft, but it doubles up as a way to put the player into an uneasy, unfamiliar, and terrifying world. Playing the game in linear order allows you to slowly creep into these unfamiliar waters. The levels are easy to commute, and allow for minor exploration to find secrets and health/ammo packs. When you run into a group of enemies, you rarely feel unprepared. That's not saying that this game is easy, because it'll tear you a new one if you don't watch out. This game isn't about unfairly pairing you with hard enemies; it’s about a gradual learning curve that teaches you to manage ammo, health and enemies. 

The enemies in Quake are also inspired by Lovecraft's novels. Otherworldly beings with a cameo appearance by the “Lord of the Wood” are just a sampler of what you are in store for. Like I touched on in my levels section, the enemies never feel too tough to beat. The first enemies you'll face are dogs and soldiers, gradually building up to Fiends, Shamblers, and Spawns (Seriously, fuck these guys). You are introduced to new weapons semi-regularly, and are given a good amount of time to find out what to use on the different enemies. An example (and quick tip) are the Zombies. You can mow the Zombies down with your shotgun, but after awhile they will stand back up to fight. Then how do you kill them? When the level first starts you are given a grenade launcher. The first enemies you see? Zombies. With this new weapon already ready to fire, you unload on the group to find that you gib (kill) the zombies for good. From that point on you know how to dispose of them, and that you shouldn't waste your grenades on enemies other than zombies (with an exception for tougher enemies).

With this dark fantasy world coming together with the level design and enemies, there's one last piece missing. Music. The music in Quake was composed by Nine-Inch-Nails. I'm not sure that I can say much else than that. The music fits the game perfectly with eerie, yet appropriate tracks. Take a look at the nail gun ammo boxes for a subtle nod.

Nobody is perfect, and sadly this port isn't an exception to that rule. The Steam version of Quake comes without the classic Nine-Inch-Nails soundtrack, and the mouse is locked horizontally. This is quickly fixed however by downloading this fix from the community page - http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=113166739 

All in all, Quake is worth the $10 price tag normally, but is an absolute steal during sales, dropping to around $5. The amazing level design, challenging enemies, and great music all come together to create one of video game histories greatest. Never think that you are finished playing Quake. While the main story may have been finished, the lively modding community is doing its job to keep Quake alive. Brand new stories, fun game modes (Team Fortress 2 has roots set in Quake), and many more changes make this game that keeps on giving. I cannot recommend this game more, you'll have to try it for yourself.

Sucesor espiritual de Doom, tal vez no llegue al carisma de este, pero Quake es el juego del que realmente beben los fps tal y como los conocemos hoy en día.

10724729.review:
Uno de los pioneros del género. Vale que antes estuvo Doom, pero este fue el primero en verdaderas 3D y con enemigos poligonales en lugar de sprites. En su día me parecía realidad virtual, una sensación de estar realmente ahí, dentro del juego, que nunca antes había sentido.

Si bien su tecnología ha sido superada, estéticamente yo lo sigo viendo excelente. La mezcla de castillos medievales y tecnología futurista en decadencia, oscuridad y metal oxidado, unidos para crean un mundo de pesadilla, le dan un ambiente único que ni siquiera las posteriores entregas de la saga han conseguido emular. Hoy en día tenemos la opción de darle un lavado de cara  a sus gráficos gracias a diversos mods y packs de texturas que lo rejuvenecen.

A nivel jugable sigue siendo un clásico, y ya se sabe que los clásicos nunca pasan de moda. Cuando algo funciona bien, seguirá funcionando bien por muchos años que pasen. Quake no necesita un gran argumento, cinemáticas, diálogos, ni scripts. Tampoco tiene coberturas ni regeneración de vida. Es pura acción frenética, simple y directa, como se hacía en los viejos tiempos, antes de que los juegos quisieran ser películas.

Los niveles están magníficamente diseñados, permitiendo rutas alternativas, y con todo lo habitual de la época: diseño laberíntico, llaves que abren puertas, secretos, etc... Una vez los conoces, pueden ser superados en 5-10 minutos sin necesidad de grabar partida, lo cual para mi gusto es uno de los puntos fuertes de su jugabilidad.

Uno de los más grandes clásicos que ha habido, aunque quizá no sea del gusto de las nuevas generaciones.

10708604.review:
10/10
this game is so well designed I was really surprised, because I played it in 2014 for the first time and didnt expected this level of quality. 
Everything in this game makes sense and fits very well, there isnt much you could take out without killing the experience. Every weapon has its place and situation where its good at (except the weak nailgun, but since you loose all your weapons every new episode you still use it).
I especially like how the guns feel. The shotgun for example has this deep sound with a quiet click sound after it and when you hit enemys with it they make a sound and cancel their attack. This makes the gun feel like you really shoot something and hurt the enemys. I cant really describe it.
The levels look similar but thats because of the age of the game, they still look interesting and dont get boring.
The soundtrack is extremely well and isnt some random metal music like in Quake 2 but only atmosspheric music which really fits the game and sometimes even creeped the fuck out of me.

ATTENTION: The game doesnt come with the soundtrack, install the Ultimate Quake Patch which not only fixes the music but also improves graphics and animation quality.

-Missing the NiN soundtrack that shipped with it back in the day
-No save feature(unless i missed it somewhere) means you need to complete an act in one sitting to beat it--"edit I totally missed it the SAVE feature is listed under new game"

[b] The Lowdown [/b]

Quake is still a classic FPS that is still a blast to play today. Its fast paced requires quick aiming skills on later difficulties. The level design is top notch, which compared to todays corrider shooters which is quite sad we have evolved backwards due to the ADHD generation. While there are only 4 acts with a handful of levels each and no real story it can be a quick play for veterans of this era. But what makes up for it is there is tons of content out there for Quake so you basically have endless hours of content. Steam workdhop would be amazing if it was p[ossible.
The graphics did not age  that well, along with the S#@% brown color palete will hurt your eyes. But this is quite easly fixed with a good number of graphics mods that make it on equal terms of todays indie games(Epsilon/Darkplaces). And last but not least be aware that the steam version is missing the NiN soundtrack that was on the release disk so long ago.

[b]Verdict:Buy It![/b]

10326974.review:
This game is the base of every modern FPS. This game was revolutionary for many reasons. One of these is the amazing Team Fortress mod (which I still play to this day), also its engine was the same base engine of all gold source games (Day of Defeat, Half-Life, TFC, and more), plus this game was one of the first FPS, and one of the first to have online multiplayer. I might not of played Quake "back in the day" but I can tell that it is still a amazing FPS and more people need to rejoin its amazing online multiplayer. I highly support this game and belive it is a gold mine of gaming history.

A good shooter from the 90s, with graphics that are a little (ok, VERY) dated now, but with good sound design in terms of overall presentation. Actually, speaking of presentation, this game has a large quantity of brown and grey, and does seem a little ugly. But it's a part of the style, so I won't complain. The gameplay (being the most important) is what you'd expect from a shooter, but the locales and enemies keep it interesting. But the game doesn't really suffer for it, the gameplay is what we're all here for, and like I said, it's fun and functional to play, and I definitely recomend it... unless you're bothered by dated grapics.
8.5/10

9906358.review: The thing is, most big budget shooters like Call of Duty have set the example for shooters, but they have set a bad example that has lead to the downfall of the FPS genre. It is actually kind of sad, really, to see that games like this one just aren;t made anymore. Quake ism prime example of a game made in a time when gameplay was put over graphics and story, which is how it should be for most FPS. One of the very first FPS rendered in true 3D graphics unlike games before it like Doom, Quake is filled with run-and-gun action, a variety of weapons and enemies, and John Romero's amazing level design. Sure, the graphics are certainly arcadie, but that is what gives the game it's charm. Unfortunately, the graphics and animations are a bit grainy on the steam version when compared to, say, the Dark Places source port. Another problem is that the music is misiing from the steam version, which isn't neccesary to enjot the game, but it would have been an nice addon. Overall, this game will give you far more action than almost any other shooter out there, and for a low price of 10 dollars, Quake is a game everyone needs to play. You are not a true FPS gamer if you haven't played Quake.

9826320.review:
Quake fu il primo sparatutto 3D della storia dei videogiochi.

Purtroppo, ho avuto occasione di giocarlo solo recentemente, modernizzandolo un pò con un engine differente (Darkplaces) il che ormai è quasi d'obbligo. Mi sono trovato molto bene e credo che sia l'engine più fedele al Quake originale, quindi posso reputare di aver giocato il gioco di cui sto scrivendo ora.

Graficamente, per i tempi, era sicuramente un passo avanti. 
Per quanto riguarda il comparto audio, sia l'atmosferica soundtrack sia tutti gli altri rumori sono stati realizzati da Trent Reznor dei Nine Inch Nails, infatti il logo della band compare nella scatola di munizioni per la sparachiodi. Lui fu chiamato da id, quando Carmack scoprì che era un grande fan di Doom, e questo è lo spendido risultato finale. 
Come giocabilità è ancora perfetta ai giorni nostri, e come longevità è molto buona. 

Il level design, in particolare, colpisce, dato che varia parecchie volte e riserva qualche riferimento al famosissimo scrittore fanta-horror H.P. Lovecraft. Questo continuo variare di ambientazione è frutto di un continuo cambio di stile per quanto riguarda il gioco. All'inizio, almeno secondo Romero, doveva essere un gdr con un protagonista semidio che combatteva i demoni con la sua ascia, un pò come Thor. Carmack rifiutò, e siccome Romero insisteva è stato costretto ad escluderlo dal progetto e licenziarlo. Alla fine, a causa di questi continui cambiamenti stilistici, il resoconto è che Quake è un fps dove tu impersoni un soldato senza nome detto ''Quakeguy'' o ''Ranger'' il quale è l'ultimo sopravvissuto dell'operazione counterstrike, cioè la resistenza agli attacchi di un'entità sconosciuta detta ''Quake'', comandata da Shub-Niggurath, la quale ha ricevuto ordine da Satana di invadere la terra e distruggere ogni forma di vita in essa. Il vostro compito sarà, appunto, usare il sistema di telestraporto per farvi strada tramite varie location dove risiede quest'entità (passando pure per la terra, qualche volta). Ci sto comunque a specificare che questa è solo la mia interpretazione del tutto, dato che è stato buttato lì in modo piuttosto ambiguo, sempre a causa del continuo cambio dei piani di sviluppo.

Come livello di difficoltà è piuttosto impegnativo, come ogni fps classico che si rispetti. Ci sono varie armi, e vari power-up. Ci sono molti segreti... TROPPI segreti, e anche ben congegnati. Tra l'altro questo gioco fu il titolo che inventò il Rocket-Jump, e fu un glitch involontario inizialmente, che venne integrato in maggior parte delle mappe verso la fine degli sviluppi perchè i devs credevano che fosse una feature niente male da aggiungere al titolo, infatti ebbe un enorme successo.
Insieme a questo, Quake diede alla luce anche vari termini come il ''Frag'', le Speedrun, ecc.

Non me la sento di dare un voto a questo capolavoro, perchè è veramente ardua come scelta, in particolare ai giorni nostri, comunque sia lo consiglio assolutamente a tutti gli amanti degli fps e delle atmosfere dark e/o lovecraftiane.

E' assolutamente un capolavoro e VA GIOCATO, anche solo per vivere un frammento di storia dei videogames. Tra l'altro è rigiocabilissimo, e ci sono così tante mod, e mappe aggiuntive che vi si aprirà un universo acquistando questo gioco!

Grazie id Software, per questa perla!

8924123.review:
No passado, muito antes de sequer saber o que era Steam, um dos FPS que eu mais gostava junto com Duke nukem, Serious Sam e Half Life era Quake, posso dizer que aproveitei bastante o Multiplayer do Quake III Arena e a campanha de Quake II, mas ainda sim era um certo peso na consciencia nunca ter fechado o primeiro jogo da franquia, esse que é um dos jogos mais revolucionários da história dos games e que é dever de qualquer jogador que se considere fã do gênero FPS.

Por onde eu posso começar a falar sobre Quake ? Bem, eu devo advertir que você com certeza vai sofrer, mesmo quem é veterano no gênero vai se deparar com armadilhas mortais, inimigos brutais que não vão medir esforçor para acabar com a sua existência, e em certos momentos você também irá enfrentar escassez de ítens.

Mas não é só dificuldade e frustração que Quake oferece, o jogo por mais desafiador que seja é muito divertido, pois tem um impressionante Level Design que irá deixar qualquer um que esteja jogando o game pela primeira vez de boca aberta com a criatividade da equipe da iD Software, pois por mais que o jogo não tenha muita variação de cenário ele nunca se torna cansativo pelas surpresas que você se depara ao longo dos 4 episódios (cada um tem em torno de 7 fases, só pra constar).

O Gameplay e gráficos são ótimos, foi o jogo que criou a base para a jogabilidade dos FPSs futuros, sobre os gráficos eu deveria advertir que é bom quem for jogar em máquinas atuais que busque um patch para deixar o jogo com suporte a Widescreen e resoluções que condizem com o padrão dos monitores atuais.

Um tesouro dos jogos de tiro em primeira pessoa, um jogo que sinto orgulho de ter finalizado, mais um jogo cinco estrelas da gloriosa iD Software, todos deveriam dar uma chance.

PRÓS:

+ Level Design Fantástico
+ Boa jogabilidade
+ Boa Longevidade e fator replay
+ Impressionante nos quesitos técnicos, Quake é pura inovação
+ Secrets!

CONTRAS:

- Pouca variação de cenário
- Alguns problemas com a Inteligencia Artificial 
- O jogo possui apenas dois chefes, há apenas um no primeiro Episódio, e o Final Boss, deveria ter um para cada Episódio
- Vou dar mais um ponto negativo para um inimigo, que eu chamo de "Amoeba", ele é uma gosma azul que fica pulando de um lado para o outro e explode perto de você, ele só aparece no final do jogo, ele não é nem um pouco interessante em nenhum aspecto e é extremamente irritante, odiei todos os meus encontros com ele

Não costumo dar notas, mas por tudo que representa Quake e toda a contribuição para os jogos menos que 9 eu considero inaceitável. Eu gostei do clima de terror que o jogo possui, no final das contas se tornou meu jogo favorito da franquia.

8747112.review: This game is fast-paced, frantic, loud, nervewracking, and a ton of fun. All of the weapons are fun to use and inventive, ranging from a most manly shotgun to the Fickle Finger of God...I mean, the Lightning Gun. The levels are well-designed deathtraps forcing you to think quick on your feet and rewarding you for exploration and skill. Quake is tough, but never made me want to rage quit during my entire playthrough of the game. All in all, this a game I can recommend on a whim to anyone who likes fast-paced old school shooters, but I should add a note to this review: If you are going to play this game (and you should, it's fantastic), you would do well to get a source port to play it on (I play Quake on a source port, hence the 1.8 hours on record). The version on Steam has no music, which is an integral part of any game's atmosphere and feel, Quake in particular. In addition, if you like eye candy (and if you have a beefy enough rig, why wouldn't you?), source ports are the way to go in that regard. You can get the necessary files right here on Steam, and for $10 USD, I don't see how you can go wrong. Quake is more than just a relic of a past era, it's an enduring classic that still manages to compel a jaded modern gamer like me to play it for hours on end. Give it a spin, if you haven't already.

8627684.review: Quake is one of the first FPS games that is fully rendered in 3D.  Now it is more of an interactive museum piece than an entertaining game, but still has a little charm for those who really fell in love with the FPS genre when it grew big.  The guns are creative and semi-traditional, as well as the enemies.  This is also one of the first games to offer enemies that will fight each other when they get caught in crossfire.  This game also was one of the first games to be openly modded, but most mods have not been carried over from the past.  Multiplayer mods have to be downloaded separately from the base game.  I still enjoy this game once in awhile, but this is one of those gems that is simply more hard rock than actual diamond.

8386395.review:
My good friend reccomended me this game, and just recently I finally got my hands on it.  

Ill admit, there was, and still is, a fair bit of hype for Quake.  In my mind, it had a lot to live up to, and it did on all accounts.  Its fast paced, challenging, balanced and well crafted.  The atmosphere is impressive, the music haunting, and the graphics, while old, have aged amazingly.  They look foreboding, satanic and deliciously evil.

It IS the seminal FPS game.  In fact, its the seminal video game.  It needs to be played to be believed.  It is up in my pantheon of my favourite games ever, and I've only played it for a few days.

Go explore the world of Quake!

8131682.review:
Doom's Big Brother.

This is the heavy hitter of id Software's library. Quake is an evolution not just for FPS games, but games as a medium.

In Quake, you fight through 4 episodes of Adrenaline pumping action, much like Doom, albeit with a much much MUCH darker atmosphere. The game is quite a lot faster than Doom, with Speedrunning being quite popular with the game. Gameplay remains unchanged from Doom. You move through the levels, killing everything in your path, then leaving via exit. 

The game doesn't have many bosses, only really 2 (End of Episode 1 and the Final Boss), but the encounters are memorable. The enemies are all interesting, and frightening, with such enemies as the giant Shambler, Ogres that hurl grenades at you, and Fiends that claw you into bits.

The maps are inspired by several dark fantasy influences, notably that of H. P. Lovecraft; most notably, the end boss of the first episode is named Chthon, and the final boss is named Shub-N iggurath, although there is little resemblance to the original literary descriptions. Some levels have Lovecraftian names as well, such as the Vaults of Zin or the Ebon Fortress. 

The original Quake runs on DOSBox, but you have the option to run GLQuake. Regardless of which version you want to play, make sure you look for source-ports, such as Quake Epsilon, or FTEQW to name a few to play the game at its max potential. The games soundtrack ran off of red book cd, so look for the Ultimate Quake patch as well if you want the great soundtrack as well (100% must install.) Also look for multiplayer source ports as well because the Quake community, like the Doom community, is still alive and kicking.

Quake is as great as Doom is, with darker tones, and faster gameplay. If you enjoyed Doom, or just wanna play an arcadey fps, Quake is the game for you.

8101434.review:
Quake, along with Doom and Doom 2, is one of the best FPS games in existence. If you liked Doom and/or have grown tired of modern military FPS games, and haven't played Quake before, then I think you really should give Quake a shot. It's a great game. (You can skip Quake 2 and not really miss much). 



The game is fast and fluid, it has the best grenade "tinkle sound" in any game, the best jump/hump sound in existence, and the guns, like Doom, are in 'the middle', so the avatar feels like some kind of supernatural tank. Unlike a lot of contemporary 'Early 3D' games that look like complete ass due to the low level of polygons, I think Quake still manages to pull it off it's look. (Though only if you play it in non-GL mode. Bilinear filtering on tiny textures looks terrible, and is one of the main reasons early 3D games (e.g. Sin) look so bad). I really like the light/shadow of the levels and the particle effects, though the levels are a bit on the brown side, admittedly.

All of the levels are weird and abstract, and don't just look like the crate storage rooms used in Quake 2 and every game since then. The low poly, highly angular level geometry helps this as well. Some of them (e.g. episode 2?) are even weird checker-board castles and such. There's also a lot of up/down movement in those levels, with the famous concept of speed running being possible by a few well placed explosions giving the player the ability to bypass huge amounts of level if they're skilled or completely lucky. There's definitely still an 'explorable' mental-map-forming aspect to a lot of the maps, much like Doom, (though it lacks an automap) and this allows the maps to contain secrets and easter eggs, something I really miss in later games. Most of all there's no attempt at cutscenes or 'story' or anything. It's like Doom in that it's pretty much pure-play. (Actually, there might be a few camera changes in the game that kind of look a bit like cutscenes?). Quake is a very non-modal game, as everything is done in that first person view. Even the choice of difficulty and a episode is performed in-game by running through portals.

I'd like to think that the reason I like Quake 1 isn't rose-tinted nostalgia, as I actually never played Quake at the time of release, but only long after I'd played Quake 2 and Half-Life. I've not played Quake as much as Doom1/2, so the initial Quake levels don't fill me with as much dread/boredom as the early Doom levels. (I've played Doom/2 practically from their time of release). Quake also isn't just a boring tech-demo, like Unreal or Quake 2 (which I also played at the contemporary time), but is fun from the first second of being in-game. 

If someone liked Doom and has grown tired of modern military FPS games, and hasn't played Quake before, then I think they they really should give Quake a shot. It's a great game. (You can skip Quake 2 and not really miss much). 

Overall: Quake is great!

7778857.review:
I am not going to dispute the quality of Quake, as I personally believe that it is one of the finest First Person Shooters ever made.  I would also argue that the game still holds up today.

What I am going to draw attention to is the simple fact that the version on sale on Steam does not have its soundtrack.  This is quite unnacceptable.  While you can get it back through mods the fact that this is necessary is an horrendous oversight that plainly should not be tolerated.  

Arguably the soundtrack is a major draw if not the major draw to this game.  Great ambient work by Trent Reznor that sets the mood  as a perfect compliment for the level design and art design.  Without it, much of the atmosphere is lost, and much of what made it a special complete experience is lost.  There simply is no excuse for leaving this out.

However, as I said, it is a fine game.  Even with that in mind, simply put we should demand better treatment for our classics than what we have on display here.

Fight against mind controlled grunts, evil hell knights and eldritch horrors as you fight to save Earth from being taken over by a supernatural force from beyond.
You will be amassing a lethal arsenal of weapons including a double-barreled shotgun, nailgun, the classic rocket launcher and much more as you fight your way through slipgate facilities, old monestaries and castles as well as caves where your foes lie in wait to send you to an early death.

4449573.review:
[b]Intro[/b]
It has taken me years to get into Quake, and yet after trying so long, it has finally clicked with me. Quake is worthy of its praise, and like most of these classic first person shooters, Quake holds up considerably well. Although it's not
one of my personal favourites I can see why so many people still play it. It just has a few subjective issues. I haven't played multiplayer but I imagine it's as good as the sequels. I also just want to boast that I finished this on the
hidden Nightmare difficulty on my first playthrough, because damn was that difficult.

[b]The Great:[/b]
++Games engine holds up miraculously and was a true innovation when released

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Brilliant soundtrack. Not included with the Steam release however, so a quick fix can add it back which is highly recommended.
+Game keeps you on your feet for long periods of time
+Levels are very rarely confusing
+Satisfying gibs
+Ultra damage is so much fun
+Chapter and difficulty selection is cool
+Although low quality, sound design is great
+Great length
+Great, original art style

[b]The Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:[/b]
+-The atmosphere is over-stated of this game
-+The last 'boss fight' is an odd way to end the game

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-The weapon roster is highly flawed. After getting the Super Nailgun, I had little reason to use the normal one. The grenade launcher was very rarely used when replaced with the rocket launcher as lobbing grenades around a corner isn't
that helpful. The original shotgun was used very little when I got the double shotgun as better accuracy isn't something you need that often. The lightning gun doesn't even get another variant and the axe is useless. You really only
get 4 useful guns for the whole game. Still, it didn't become boring.
-Enemies are annoying to fight with frustrating tactics. It's not that bad and you get used to it pretty quick, and their design is decent enough with predictable firing patterns, but they're not amazing.
-Sound quality is trash, but that's to be expected for a game from 1996
-Occasionally cheap enemy spawning makes for artificially difficult sections. Rare case, though.
-The first boss fight is the easiest boss fight I've ever experienced

[b]The Horrible:[/b]
--I think the thing besides the weapons and enemies that kept me away from this game for so long was the level design. It's not bad per say, I just don't find it very enjoyable personally, and I think it did detract from my enjoyment.

Sound: 4/10
Graphics: 9.5/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Content/Replayability: 3/10
Overall: 8/10

Awards:
Game of the Year - 1996

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Great game. Not sure I'll be replaying it any time within the next few years, but it's definitely an experience that any FPS fan should try.

175169.review:
Quake is a game that is difficult to describe accurately. It is an experience that takes everything you think you know about first person shooters gets thrown out the window and replaced by a new standard.

Quake is the first truly 3D first person game, no longer are the enemies and objects in the world represented by mere 2D sprites but are instead rendered in full glorious 3D letting you view them from every angle. This also opens up the maps and up, down, left and right are now all equal and most all be checked to find that one pesky monster shooting at you.

The weapons are plentiful and varied from the grenade launcher which, thanks to the 3D engine, can be used to bounce grenades off walls and ceilings to hit enemies that are hiding to the iconic lightning gun and extremely entertaining nail gun. All the weapons have excellent sound effects and animations and use them efficiently leaves you feeling powerful.

Using the weapons efficiently however requires more skill than ever before, aiming in the general direction of your enemies will not suffice and only a steady mouse hand will prevail against the alien hordes.

Map design is of an equally high quality with a great emphasis on atmospheric lightning and a decent about of nooks and crannies to find hidden goodies in. The multi-player maps are equally well balanced and will reward only the most skilled among you.

Throughout the maps, both single- and multi-player, you will encounter power-ups that grant you various short lived bonuses such as increased damage, more health, invisibility and other good stuff. Knowledge of their locations can quickly turn defeat into victory for the observant player.

Graphically there is not much to say. Quake simply sets the bar and it is up to the rest of the world to follow.

An excellent soundtrack sets the mood throughout the game and creates a dark and tense atmosphere that only increases as you progress through the levels.

All in all Quake is perhaps the greatest first person shooter every released simply because of how many firsts it can boast. Without it nothing would be the same and for that reason alone this is a game that no self respecting gamer can go without.

3552440.review: One of the greatest games ever.

163108.review:
Oh Quake, how I love thee.  Quake II was my introduction into First-Person Shooter, and after I had absorbed as much of it as I could I went to its predecessor and played that.  And boy are they different games.

The funny thing about Quake is how different the games have been.  First there is Quake with a gothic feel that isn’t far from the Doom mold. Then you have Quake 2, which wasn’t intended on being a Quake game until they were unable to gain the rights they were looking for, and decided to just use the name Quake II.  It has a very technological theme with aliens.  After which there was Quake III Arena, which took all the great things created and learned from Quake and Quake II’s multiplayer, making almost a third setting/storyline, with characters from previous ID titles.  And finally there is Quake 4, which is a direct sequel to Quake II, back the the technological aliens.  And there is rumor of the next Quake game going back to the gothic style.

While the story isn’t entirely there, Quake is ultimately an excellent game.  And maybe it’s simply because I just played all the great games in the right order.  Where each game fed into the next, and really displayed how they were truly remarkable.

1655436.review:
Truly one of my favorite video games of all time. For the time, the graphics were stunning and unfathomable. Even in an age of much better graphics, I still thoroughly enjoy looking about the levels and marveling at the superb design. The soundtrack is very fitting with the atmosphere that is placed around and creates a sense of immersion. The story is not clearly explained and is not emotional or anything but compelling enough to keep you blasting through enemies and exploring the environment. The gameplay is what to be expected, a fantasically crafted simple yet enjoyable first person shooter that screams everything is classic about this game. I would recommend this game to anyone in the world, even if they do not play video games often. This is a must play for anyone and everyone, this fine piece of gaming history should be known to all. 
 
Quake is not just a game, but a whole culture that has culminated a certain part of video game history that still stands today in 2016. As one of my favorite games, even today, I can recommend this game to anyone. The graphics are not the absolute best, but were still revolutionary at the time. The sound is nostalgic to all of those that stayed up late nights playing with their friends blasting eachother with the crazy fun arsenal of weapnry. The environments took you to places that were quite unique for the time and somehow made sense to be designed the way that they were and not only that, but enjoyable to the average gamer. Furthermore, I think if the graphics get to you now, there are still modders that have improved on that to either get new players to experience it or bring some older players a new experience.

5163709.review:
Quake - это та самая легендарная игра, сделавшая технологический прорыв вслед за DooM, а также движок и игровой процесс которой оказали огромное влияние на все следующие 3D-игры.

Кто-то думает, что сюжета в Quake нет. Сразу видно - не читали они README.TXT, где всё расписано в достаточной степени.
Сюжет: люди проводили эксперименты по телепортации и внезапно открыли портал в другое измерение, а в этом измерении обитает некий злодей по имени Quake, который вторгается на Землю со своей адской армией. В общем-то, ничего нового после DooM - тамошний сюжет также завязан на вторжение армии из ада в результате экспериментов по телепортации. Нетрудно догадаться, что сюжет и движок Half-Life был сделан на основе сюжета и движка Quake - точно так же вторжение злодеев из другого измерения через открытый портал.

Дизайн уровней сложный - не думайте, что получится пройти игру, идя только вперёд, оставляя за собой горы трупов. Это не треш. Обязательно будете бегать в поисках ключей и переключателей, а может даже получится и найти секреты на уровнях. Тот, кто впервые играет в Quake, обязательно столкнётся с тем, что боссов так просто не убить - мозги включать тоже придётся, хоть "головоломки" не из сложных.

Превосходная игра, заложившая основы современных стрелялок. Не то что ваши дегенеративные Call of Duty, от которых только тошнит.

Оценка: 10/10

Это классика, которую необходимо знать.

1499939.review:
A very important game in gaming history. It added and extra dimension when it came to FPS's and it was a landmark achievement at the time. Today, however, the third dimension is used in pretty much every game now, but Quake still holds up as a whole. It plays like a silky-smooth old-school FPS with deep/nonlinear level exploration, fast-paced projectile dodging, and a variety of differentweapons and powerups used to kill a variety of  monsters. If you like old-school FPS games, you'll love this.

There is one major flaw however, one massive issue that brings the whole game down, and it's not Quake's fault, it's Steam's. There is none of the original music. When Quake was orignally released, there were two discs: one with the game, and one with the music. When they released it onto Steam, they didn't bother putting the music in with it. Why? It takes so much away from the game's atmosphere. Oh well, the gameplay is still fantastic and that's all that matters really.

Simply put, my favorite FPS of all time.  Impeccable level design, great enemies with really good AI for the time, and an environment and mob placement that actually lends itself to be legitimately scary.  It has surprises that you're usually ready for, but you're not the golden god you are in most FPS games where after the initial startle, you realize you can not be stopped and then wait until the next cheap shock.  

Brilliant weapons, an awesome soundtrack and very cool odes to Lovecraftian lore make this a title that no gamer should ever have to claim they have not played.  If you love the Halos and Call of Duties now and have not taken a step back in time to play this gem, then make sure to put it on  your list.  You won't regret it.

454891.review: There's not much I can say about Quake you haven't heard elsewhere. It's fun, it's dark, it's immersive, and it firmly established many of the conventions of FPS gaming we now take for granted. There would be no Team Fortress 2 without Quake, and that is why I wield the Original with pride. Id Software may have moved on to bigger things with Rage, but plans for Doom 4 make me believe that a new Quake may lurk somewhere beyond the horizon. It's important to know your roots in gaming, and while I got my online start in Starsiege: Tribes, my favorite singleplayer FPS of yore was probably Quake, if not Half-Life. Quake gave me my love of shotguns and grenade launchers and if an FPS cannot deliver me satisfying examples of such, then it does not measure up to my expectations for what constitutes adequate firepower. You can keep your assault rifles, throwing knives and tactical nukes. Give me a little buckshot and a little boom, and I will give you delicious interdimensional demon gibs.

1616822.review:
Quake is like Doom except the physics feel much nicer and you can jump, aim up and down and there's an increased emphasis on movement in general. The trade off is that there's smaller groups of enemies (rarely more than two at a time) and they're all a bit more bullet-spongey. The weapons can also be a tad unimaginative (no BFG here, just a gun that shoots lightning and chews through it's max amount of ammo in seconds).

A lot of people dislike this game's visuals for relying a lot on the color brown. Personally, I don't mind this, as I feel that the more complex lighting and architecture of the maps (compared to Doom) compensates for this. That and the crappy low-poly monster models (that are still surprisingly well animated) combine with the rusted look of the game to create a wonderful aesthetic of low-tech creepiness. (I'd compare it to Silent Hill, but no part of Quake is ever set in a foggy town in the countryside - though there is at least one user-made map set in Innsmouth.)

This game also has excellent sound design by NIN's Trent Reznor. Don't bother with that EpiQuake junk, the game's audio is perfect enough as it is ... and on that note, I have to explain exactly why I'm giving this a thumbs down, even though I've just been gushing about the game.

It's because the Steam version doesn't include Trent Reznor's ambient soundtrack that Quake played off it's CD as in-game music. Unlike Hexen, there aren't any MIDI tracks or anything for the game to fall back on if the CD is missing - just nothing. The in-game sounds of wind and flickering torches are slightly more audible, and that's as good a compromise as you get.

Now, I can understand the absence if it was a rights issue with Reznor, but that supposedly wasn't the case. Apparently, it was because when id put the Steam version of the game together (which runs in DOSBox) they couldn't figure out how to simply rip the tracks off the CD in OGG format and configure DOSBox to load those files in lieu of redbook audio. Maybe John Carmack was too busy working on his new engine for whatever that game no one cared about was called.

Regardless, get Quake if you can find the original CD release on the cheap - which you probably will, as it's not a particularly rare game, nor one as valued by collectors as Doom (though be careful not to buy a  shareware version by accident). Alternatively, wait and see if this ever shows up on GOG.com - as those guys will probably put more effort into a basic digital release of this game than it's own developers.

------------------

TL;DR, Quake is a very good game, but don't buy it here or you will get a version without music.

1042591.review: This game is legendary in the FPS genre for good reason. At the time, it was a technical milestone for its superbly impressive 3D engine (which is quite dated, of course), which would later go on to power games like Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight and Half-Life. It pioneered online multiplayer. It spawned a series of FPS's responsible for defining the genre throughout the 90's and beyond, though Quake 3 is probably the most widely-known of the lot these days. Ultimately, Quake 1 is an insanely fun, action-packed FPS that I can do nothing but recommend to everyone who enjoys the FPS genre. It's both great to see the history of the genre as well as still being an absolute blast to play.

48694.review:
While modern iterations of the Quake franchise continue to attract new players, there has recently been a clear recognition of the true importance of the very first Quake in shaping the multiplayer FPS games we play today. Clients such as ezQuake, nQuake, and FuhQuake all continue to prolong the multiplayer life of this true classic as well as adding the various options, toolsets, and graphical improvements that most are familiar with today. From Dennis 'Thresh' Fong winning John Carmack's Ferrari 328 at the 1997 Red Annihilation Tournament to the current Quake Live MLG, CPL, Intel Masters, Tek9, and QuakeCon events (to mention just a few), there has rarely been a lapse in the competitive interest this game continues to generate.

It is now 20 years since the game's release and there are simply too many happy memories to recount. Without a doubt one of the greatest games ever made and an essential title in any game collection.

1219643.review:
released by id Software on June 22, 1996, Quake was programmed by John Carmack, Michael Abrash and John Cash. The level and scenarios were designed by American McGee, Sandy Petersen, John Romero and Tim Willits. The graphics were designed by Adrian Carmack, Kevin Cloud. Music and sound design was by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails fame.

The game engine developed for Quake, the Quake engine, popularized several major advances in the 3D game genre: polygonal models instead of prerendered sprites; full 3D level design instead of a 2.5D map; prerendered lightmaps; and allowing end users to partially program the game (in this case with QuakeC), which popularized fan-created modifications (mods).

422902.review: This is still after all these years the game I run to when I need to have fun.  ID still pretty much owns the genre of "I just want to kill everything with this giant gun, flick a switch, find a key, find a new gun, and kill some more."  I still love Doom, Wolfenstein, and the rest of the Quake series; but playing the original Quake - with Trent Reznor's awesome soundtrack pumping behind the cacophony of explosions, zombie moans and chainsaw wails - takes me right back to the summer when the demo came out (THANK YOU PC GAMER) and my father and I ran to the store that night to buy a computer fast enough to play it.

671489.review: Quite simply an icon of PC gaming among all genres and times. If you consider yourself a first person shooter enthusiast and haven't played this title, then your views are without context. Fourteen years after its release, Quake is very much among my top three FPS experiences. Do yourself a favour, get with the times and pick up a copy today.

241645.review: Aside from DooM, this is really the game that started it all. The nostalgia factor is extremely heavy for those gamers who were around for the birth of the FPS, hardware accelerated 3D engines, online gaming, mods, clans, and the birth of a then underground movement known as the "gaming community". Quake took everything DooM did and flushed it out to really kick start the PC FPS community we know and love today. GldSource came from this engine/game (and really, in some respects, Valve). TF came from the Quake community. Do you know how many dozens of current game engines are based on original Quake code? If you started your FPS fandom with Half-Life, you were actually a generation late. DooM may be the grandaddy of the FPS, but Quake is still YOUR daddy whether you know it or not.

2149092.review:
Quake Pioneered the following innovation in First Person Shooters:
-Recharging personal shields (every FPS today copies it)
-Dual wielding
-Dedicated grenade button
-Dedicated melee button (melee is actually useful in Quake)
-Complex characters (Ranger, Shub-Niggurath)
-Involving and deep storyline
-Saved PC gaming
-Made LAN parties cool
-Saving and sharing replays
-First ever FPS to include a map editor
-Perfectly streamlined online play
-Vehicles
-It is so good that games nowadays are referred to as "Quake clones," and some, like Unreal, try to be a "Quake killer"
-Orchestral music (before it everything was just bleepbloop synthesized music)
-AI that becomes more intelligent on higher difficulties instead of just having more health.
